{{Bahá'í sidebar}} The '''Bahá'í Faith in Guyana''' was first mentioned in Bahá'í sources as early as 1916,{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |origyear = 1916-17 |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-6.html | pages = 31–32}} the first [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'ís]] visited as early as 1927{{cite web | title = A brief history | work = Official Webpage of the National Assembly of the Baha'is of Guyana | publisher = National Assembly of the Baha'is of Guyana | year = 2009 | url = http://www.gy.bahai.org/history.html | doi = | accessdate = 2009-08-10}}{{Citation | title = In Memoriam | journal = The Bahá'í World | volume = XVIII | publisher = Bahá'í World Centre | pages = 733–736, 809–811 | year = 1986 | url =http://bahai-library.org/books/bw18/800-825.html | isbn = 0-85398-234-1 | author = prepared under the supervision of the Universal House of Justice.}} but the community was founded in [[Guyana]] in 1953 with the beginning of the arrival of coordinated [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]] and from Guyanese converts. The community elected the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] in 1955 and an independent [[National Spiritual Assembly]] in 1977.{{cite magazine | title = Six pillars added to House of Justice; Surinam and Fr. Guiana |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1977 | number = 555 |pages=8–9 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=09&page=524}} The country has experienced large migrations{{cite web | last = Beaie | first = Sonkarley Tiatun | authorlink = | title = Chapter I - National Populations Trends: Size, Growth, and Distribution | work = Population and Housing Census | publisher = Bureau of Statistics Guyana | date = 2007-09-19 | url =http://www.statisticsguyana.gov.gy/pubs/Chapter1_National_Population_Trends.pdf | format = pdf | doi = | accessdate = 2009-09-05}} and the size of the Bahá'í community has also dramatically changed. In the most recent cycle the 2002 national census showed about 0.1%, or 500, Bahá'ís mostly in three of its [[Regions of Guyana|Regions]] though Bahá'ís were noted in every Region.{{cite web | last = Beaie | first = Sonkarley Tiatun | authorlink = | title = Chapter II - Population Composition | work = Population and Housing Census | publisher = Bureau of Statistics Guyana | date = 2007-09-19 | url =http://www.statisticsguyana.gov.gy/pubs/Chapter2_Population_Composition.pdf | format = pdf | doi =| accessdate = 2009-09-05}} However, by 2005 the [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] estimated there were some 13,000 Bahá'ís.{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-07-04}} Bahá'ís are now widely distributed across Guyana and are represented in all major racial groups and regions.{{cite web|title=Population and Housing Census 2002 Census |url=http://www.statisticsguyana.gov.gy/pubs/Chapter2_Population_Composition.pdf|year=2002 |publisher= Statistics Bureau|accessdate=15 August 2009}} The Bahá'í community, while relatively small, is well known for its emphasis on unity, non-involvement in politics and its work in issues such as literacy and youth issues.{{cite web |title=Independent Evaluation of Youth Can Move the World |url=http://www.varqafoundation.org/reports1.html |date=July 2000 |publisher=Varqa Foundation |accessdate=15 August 2009}}{{cite web |title=Religion can help fight AIDS, says study |url=http://www.onecountry.org/e191/e191fnl.pdf |date=Dec 2007 |publisher=One Country |accessdate=15 August 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517115710/http://www.onecountry.org/e191/e191fnl.pdf |archive-date=2008-05-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }} == Early Phase == === `Abdu'l-Bahá's Tablets of the Divine Plan === [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], the son of the founder of the religion, wrote a series of letters, or [[tablets (religious)|tablets]], to the followers of the religion in the [[United States]] in 1916–1917; these letters were compiled together in the book titled [[Tablets of the Divine Plan]]. The sixth of the tablets was the first to mention [[Latin America]]n regions and was written on April 8, 1916, but was delayed in being presented in the United States until 1919 — after the end of [[World War I]] and the [[Spanish flu]]. The first actions on the part of Bahá'í community towards Latin America were that of a few individuals who made trips to [[Mexico]] and [[South America]] near or before this unavailing in 1919, including Mr. and Mrs. Frankland, and [[Hands of the Cause#Appointed posthumously by Shoghi Effendi|Roy C. Wilhelm]], and [[Martha Root]]. Root's travels to Latin America began in the summer of 1919.{{cite web | last = Allmar | first = Husayn | title = Martha Root’s Journey to Chile | work = The Chilean Temple Initiative | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of the United State | year = 2007 | url = http://www.chilean-temple.org/content/view/27/45/ | accessdate = 2008-03-05 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080323081114/http://www.chilean-temple.org/content/view/27/45/ | archivedate = 2008-03-23 | deadurl = yes | df = }} The sixth tablet was translated and presented by [[Mirza Ahmad Sohrab]] on April 4, 1919, and published in [[Star of the West (Bahá'í magazine)|Star of the West]] magazine on December 12, 1919.{{cite book| last = Abbas | first = 'Abdu'l-Bahá |others=Mirza Ahmad Sohrab (trans. and comments) | title = Tablets, Instructions and Words of Explanation] |date=April 1919 | url =http://bahai-library.com/abdulbaha_tablets_instructions_explanation}}
"His Holiness [[Christ]] says: Travel ye to the East and to the West of the world and summon the people to the [[Kingdom of God]]. ... the republic of Mexico ... to be familiar with the [[Spanish language]] ... [[Guatemala]], [[Honduras]], [[El Salvador|Salvador]], [[Nicaragua]], [[Costa Rica]], [[Panama]] and the seventh country [[Belize]] ... Attach great importance to the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous]] population of America ... Likewise the islands of ... [[Cuba]], [[Haiti]], [[Puerto Rico]], [[Jamaica]], ... [[Bahama]] Islands, even the small [[Watling Island]] ... [[Haiti]] and [[Santo Domingo]] ... the islands of [[Bermuda]] ... the republics of the continent of South America—[[Colombia]], [[Ec­or]], [[Peru]], [[Brazil]], [[the Guianas]], [[Bolivia]], [[Chile]], [[Argentina]], [[Uruguay]], [[Paraguay]], [[Venezuela]]; also the islands to the north, east and west of South America, such as [[Falkland Islands]], the [[Galápagos Islands|Galapagòs]], [[Juan Fernández Islands|Juan Fernandez]], [[Trinidad and Tobago|Tobago and Trinidad]]. ..."
Following the release of these tablets and then `Abdu'l-Bahá's death in 1921, a few Bahá'ís began moving to or at least visiting Latin America. In 1927 [[Leonora Armstrong]] made public mention of the religion in the capital city of [[Georgetown, Guyana|Georgetown]] of what was then [[British Guiana]]. === Seven Year Plan and succeeding decades === [[Shoghi Effendi]], who was named `Abdu'l-Bahá's successor, wrote a [[Telegraphy|cable]] on May 1, 1936 to the [[Bahá'í administration#National|Bahá'í Annual Convention]] of the United States and Canada, and asked for the systematic implementation of `Abdu'l-Bahá's vision to begin. In his cable he wrote:
"Appeal to assembled delegates ponder historic appeal voiced by 'Abdu'l-Bahá in ''Tablets of the Divine Plan''. Urge earnest deliberation with incoming National Assembly to insure its complete fulfillment. First century of Bahá'í Era drawing to a close. Humanity entering outer fringes most perilous stage its existence. Opportunities of present hour unimaginably precious. Would to God every State within American Republic and every Republic in American continent might ere termination of this glorious century embrace the light of the Faith of Bahá'u'lláh and establish structural basis of His World Order."{{cite book |first = Shoghi |last = Effendi |authorlink = Shoghi Effendi |origyear = |year = 1947 |title = Messages to America |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Committee |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |oclc= 5806374 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/MA/ma-16.html.iso8859-1?query=Appeal%7Cto%7Cassembled%7Cdelegates%7Cponder%7Chistoric&action=highlight#gr2 | page = 6}}
Following the May 1st cable, another cable from Shoghi Effendi came on May 19 calling for permanent [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]] to be established in all the countries of Latin America. The Bahá'í [[National Spiritual Assembly]] of the United States and Canada was appointed the Inter-America Committee to take charge of the preparations. In 1936 Dudley M. Blakely, after becoming a Bahá'í in 1920, embarked with Elsa, his wife, on worldwide travels to promote the religion and traveled to Guyana for several weeks to promulgate the religion. During the 1937 Bahá'í North American Convention, Shoghi Effendi cabled advising the convention to prolong their deliberations to permit the delegates and the National Assembly to consult on a plan that would enable Bahá'ís to go to Latin America as well as to include the completion of the outer structure of the [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] in Wilmette, Illinois. In 1937 the ''First Seven Year Plan'' (1937–44), which was an international plan designed by Shoghi Effendi, gave the American Bahá'ís the goal of establishing the Bahá'í Faith in every country in Latin America. With the spread of American Bahá'ís communities and assemblies began to form in 1938 across Latin America. == Establishment of the community == The first Bahá'í to settle in Guyana was Dr. Malcolm King, a Jamaican, who traveled from his home in the United States in 1953 via [[Trinidad]].{{cite web | title = The History of the Bahá'í Faith in Trinidad and Tobago | work = Official Webpage of the National Assembly of the Baha'is of Trinidad and Tobago | publisher = National Assembly of the Baha'is of Trinidad and Tobago | date = 2009-05-25 | url =http://www.bahaitt.org/history.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2009-08-10}} In 1955 the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] was elected in Guyana in [[Georgetown, Guyana|Georgetown]]. Following the election of the regional National Spiritual Assembly of South America in 1950, in 1957 this assembly was split into two - basically northern/eastern South America and one of the western/southern South America.{{cite web | url = http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63&chapter=1 | title = The Bahá'í Faith: 1844–1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953–1963| author = Compiled by [[Hands of the Cause]] Residing in the Holy Land | pages = 22, 46, 70}} In 1963 smaller groups of Bahá'ís were known in Campelville, Kitty and Lodge Village (now suburbs of Georgetown), Grove and [[Providence, Guyana|Providence]] (both in [[Demerara-Mahaica]] in East Bank Demerara), and MacKenzie (now part of Linden).[[File:Gy-map.png|left|thumb]] In August 1965 the Bahá'ís of Georgetown hosted a regional conference with [[Hand of the Cause]] Jalál Kházeh and Bahá'ís from British, French and Dutch Guiana, northern Brazil, eastern Venezuela and Trinidad attending.{{cite magazine | title = Regional teaching Congress held: in Georgetown |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1965 | number = 416 | page =5 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In early February, 1968 Hand of the Cause [[Rúhíyyih Khanum]] visited giving public talks, visiting a school for the blind, and civic leaders.{{cite magazine | title = Surinam and Guiana Greet Hand of the Cause of God |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1968 | number = 450 | page =6 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In 1970 the Bahá'ís of Guyana, Surinamé and French Guiana first elected a regional [[National Spiritual Assembly]].{{cite book | last = Lamb | first = Artemus | title = The Beginnings of the Bahá'í Faith in Latin America:Some Remembrances, English Revised and Amplified Edition | publisher = M L VanOrman Enterprises |date=November 1995 | location = 1405 Killarney Drive, West Linn OR, 97068, United States of America | url = http://bahai-library.com/lamb_bahai_latin_america}} Rúhíyyih Khanum represented the [[Universal House of Justice]] at the convention to elect the assembly.{{cite magazine | title = First National Baha'i Convention of the Baha'is of Guyana, Surinam and French Guiana |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1970 | number = 476 | page =13 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} There were 54 delegates representing at least 10 assemblies in Guyana, 3 in Surinamé and 3 in French Guiana. The members elected were Jamshid Ar-jomandi; Henry Dolphin; August Holland; Cheryl Plerre; Ellen Widmer; Mr. Rivadavia da Silva, Eileen Hill, Ivan Fraser, and Daisy Hahnfeld. While there Rúhíyyih Khanum again spoke to the public press and civic leaders this time including then President [[Arthur Chung]]. Her comments dwelt on the [[Bahá'í teachings]] of the oneness of humanity and ending racial prejudices.{{cite magazine | title = The Great Safari of Hand of the Cause Ruhiyyih Khanum; Conventions in Ec­or and Georgetown |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1971 | number = 483 |pages=16–17 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} The first regional Baha'i Youth Conference was held in [[Paramaribo]], December 29 through 31, 1972.{{cite magazine | title = International Youth Conference, Paramaribo, Surinam |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1973 | number = 506 | page =7 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} The Conference was especially for Baha'i youth of Trinidad and Tobago, Aruba, Bonaire, Curaçao, Guyana, Surinam and French Guiana. A sixth youth conference was held in 1979.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1979 | number = 577 |ISSN =0043-8804 | page =18 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} Meanwhile, in 1975 the National Assembly asked for guidance from the Universal House of Justice on the approach to respond to requirements of national service which advised such service for agriculture was approved while trying to minimize the chances of service requiring combat.{{cite book | last = Bahá'u'lláh | first = | authorlink = Bahá'u'lláh |last2 = 'Abdu'l-Bahá| first2 = | author2-link ='Abdu'l-Bahá |last3 = Effendi| first3 = Shoghi| author3-link =Shoghi Effendi |author4=Helen Hornby | title = Lights of Guidance - A Bahá'í Reference File | publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust, 1999| year = 1988 | location = New Dehli | url = http://bahai-library.com/hornby_lights_guidance_2&chapter=4 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-81-85091-46-4 |pages=409–10 }} Early in 1976 the first members of the [[Macushi]] and [[Wai-Wai (people)|Wai Wai]] tribes joined the religion.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Ties strengthened with three tribes |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1976 | number = 544 | page =8 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In December 1976 the assembly was able to officially incorporate.{{cite magazine | title =National Assembly incorporated |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1977 | number = 551 | page =14 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In 1977 the Surinamé and French Guiana communities organized their own national assembly and Guyana elected an independent assembly. The elected members of the first National Assembly of Guyana were Sheila Dolphin, Henry Dolphin, Ellen Widmer, Frank Sheffey, Ivan Fraser, Eileen Hill, David Morris, Rooplall Doodnauth, and Krishna Seegopaul. Meanwhile, pioneers continue to arrive in Guyana.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Scotland |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1979 | number = 574 | page =19 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In July and August 1980 Shanaz Furudi, a [[Bahá'í Faith in India|Bahá'í from India]] toured Guyana and addressing the public and offering training for Bahá'í institutions. Guyanese residents of Asian [[India]]n extraction learned of the religion's situation there. While she was there the first Bahá'í of the Arecuna (see [[Pemon]]) converted.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Guyana |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1981 | number = 598 |ISSN=0195-9212 | page =11 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} Guyanese citizens have also moved to other countries where some have become Bahá'ís as well.{{Citation | last = | first = | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Ramsharran, Benjamin W. | newspaper = The Hartford Courant | date = 2001-02-11 | url =http://bahai-library.com/newspapers/2001/021001-1.html | accessdate = 2009-09-05 }} == Modern community == Since its inception the religion has had involvement in [[socio-economic development]] beginning by giving greater freedom to women,{{cite web | last = Momen | first = Moojan | title = History of the Baha'i Faith in Iran | work = draft "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" | publisher = Bahai-library.com | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_iran#9.%20Social%20and%20economic%20development | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-10-16}} promulgating the promotion of female education as a priority concern,{{cite journal | last = Kingdon | first = Geeta Gandhi | title = Education of women and socio-economic development | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | year = 1997 | url = http://bahai-library.com/kingdon_education_women_development }} and that involvement was given practical expression by creating schools, agricultural coops, and clinics. In Guyana in 1980 saw the first Bahá'í women's conference. A main topic through the conference was the role of women in religion as well topics dealing with life in the tropics.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Guyana |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1981 | number = 602 |ISSN=0195-9212 | page =15 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In April 1981 more than 60 artists attended a workshop set up by five Bahá'í artists which presented workshops emphasizing spiritual issues and introduced Bahá'í [[Sandpainting|sand-painter]] [[David Villasenor]] to the Guyanese.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Guyana |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1981 | number = 602 |ISSN=0195-9212 | page =12 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} The religion entered a new phase of activity when a message of the [[Universal House of Justice]] dated 20 October 1983 was released.{{cite journal |title= The Baha'i Faith 1957–1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | first = Moojan | last = Momen |author2=Smith, Peter | year = 1989 | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957-1988 |volume = 19 | journal = Religion | pages=63–91 |doi= 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8}} Bahá'ís were urged to seek out ways, compatible with the [[Bahá'í teachings]], in which they could become involved in the social and economic development of the communities in which they lived. World-wide in 1979 there were 129 officially recognized Bahá'í socio-economic development projects. By 1987, the number of officially recognized development projects had increased to 1482. In the 1980s the Guyanese Bahá'í community's established an Office of Social and Economic Development which consulted with rural communities on a needs assessment which focused on the issue of literacy.{{cite book | editor1-first = James | editor1-last = Lynch | editor2-first = Sohan |editor2-last = Modgil | author1= Pamela O'Toole |author2= Brian O'Toole | title = Education and development: tradition and innovation, Volume 3 | publisher = Continuum International Publishing Group | year = 1997 | location = | pages = 180–1 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Kv0PgL5EMhgC&pg=PA180&lpg=PA180 | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-304-32888-X}} In 1984 Bahá'í Frank Fernandes, a native of Guyana, was the guest of honor at a dinner of civic leaders followed by a piano recital at, and a fundraiser for,{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Guyana |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1985 | number = 648 |ISSN=0195-9212 | page =15 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} the National Cultural Centre for an audience of 250.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Guyana |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1985 | number = 602 |ISSN=0195-9212 | page =16 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} One response of the community was to contact the Bahá'í communities in Canada, the US, and the UK. Together they made arrangements for 40,000 reading books which became the basis of libraries in 65 villages. Training workshops were organized with the cooperation of the Ministry of Education which were developed in the context of the [[Macushi]] and [[Wapishana|Wapashana]] languages. As recently as 2000 Bahá'ís were noted contributing to the training of 1500 teachers for this project.{{cite web | last = Universal House of Justice | first = | authorlink = Universal House of Justice | title = Ridván Letter, 2000 | work = Ridvan Messages from the Universal House of Justice | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | year = 2000 | url =http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ridvan_2000 | accessdate = 2009-08-30}} Also in the 1980s some Bahá'ís opened a private school - the [[School of the Nations (Guyana)|School of the Nations]] in Guyana, an all age private [[Bahá'í inspired school]]. There are 650 full-time students (representing 22 nationalities) and 300 adults who pursue the [[International General Certificate of Secondary Education]] in the evenings.{{Citation | last = O'Toole | first = Brian | title = Brian O'Toole - Guyana | date = September 2005 | url =http://www.bci.org/pioneer-post-uk/05july/guy.htm | journal = Pioneer-Post UK | volume = 18 | issue = 05 | doi =| id = }}{{cite web | title = Why Baha'i - Ted Taylor | work = Why Baha'i | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of the United States | date = 2007-12-07 | url =http://www.bahai.us/why-bahai-ted-taylor | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-09-05}}{{Citation | last = Bahá'í International Community | first = | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = One World Cafe puts unity on the men | newspaper = Baha'i World News Service | date = 2004-05-05 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/294 | accessdate = 2009-05-05}} In 1988 represented a year of multiple events.{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Guyana |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1988 | number = 691 |ISSN=0195-9212 | page =15 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In April an inter-Guyana conference of Bahá'ís was held. In May Bahá'í youth mobilized for activities from which over 200 converted. In June two Bahá'í physicians from Great Britain visited Guyana for two weeks to conduct lectures and work at [[Georgetown Public Hospital]] and then toured the country at Bahá'í events. In 1992 the government of Guyana honored the Bahá'ís by releasing stamps overprinted noting the [[Bahá'í Holy Year]] in 1992.{{cite web | last = maintained by Tooraj | first = Enayat | authorlink = | title = Bahá'í Stamps | work = Bahá'í Philately | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | url =http://bahai-library.com/stamps/BahaiStamps.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2009-09-05}} In 1999 the national assembly contributed to the dialogue on the reform of the [[Constitution of Guyana]].{{cite web | title = Submission to the Constitution Reform Commission | work = | publisher = The National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Guyana | date = April 1999 | url = http://www.gy.bahai.org/constitution99.html | doi = | accessdate = 2009-09-05}} In the 2000s Bahá'í organizations cooperated with projects to fight the spread of poverty{{cite web | title = Guyana | work = Areas of Work → Poverty | publisher = Baha'i International Community | url = http://www.bic.org/areas-of-work/poverty/guyana | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-09-05}} and AIDs among youth - as well as studies on the effectiveness of religion in motivating people to deal with social ills.{{Citation | last = Bahá'í International Community | first = | title = Religion could help fight AIDS, says study | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 2007-04-24 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/520 | accessdate = 2009-09-05}} In 2002 the Bahá'ís collectively and individually contributed to the Guyana Peace Education Institute at its inauguration{{cite web|title=Report on inaugural general meeting |work= |publisher=Peace Education Institute |date=2002-05-08 |url=http://www.sdnp.org.gy/pei/peireport.doc |format= |doi= |accessdate=2009-09-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030904144827/http://www.sdnp.org.gy/pei/peireport.doc |archivedate=September 4, 2003 }} and to discussions on reform held at the Muslim Youth Organization office.{{cite web | title = Contents of The Guyana Peace Education Institute - Report on Symposium | work = | publisher = The Guyana Peace Education Institute | date = 2002-01-26 | url = http://www.sdnp.org.gy/pei/sumworkshop.html | doi = | accessdate = 2009-09-05}} Youth workshops were noted in 2006 presenting patterns for change to cycles of social ills like [[alcoholism]] and [[family violence]]{{Citation | last = Bahá'í International Community | first = | title = Guyana youth try to "move the world" | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 2006-03-09 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/430 | accessdate = 2009-09-05}} and participated in national discussions and exhibitions on ethnic relations by the National Commission on Ethnic Relations in 2006{{cite web | title = Statement of the MSF National Religious Leaders Conversation | work = Publications | publisher = Ethnic Relations Commission | year = 2006 | url =http://www.ethnicrelations.org.gy/publications/reports/2006%20Annual%20Report.pdf | format = pdf | doi = | accessdate = 2009-09-05}} and dialogues on religious tolerance.{{cite press release | title = Guyana’s religious tolerance can be a role model for the world | publisher = Guyanan Federal Government | date = 2008-11-20 | url = http://opnew.op.gov.gy/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=297:guyanas-religious-tolerance-can-be-a-role-model-for-the-world- | accessdate = 2009-09-05}} The Bahá'í community was also noted for its support for inter-religious activities through the Inter-Religious Organization (IRO), a nongovernmental umbrella organization for Christian, Hindu, Islamic, and Bahá'í organizations, and the Ethnic Relations Commission.{{cite web | author = U.S. State Department | title = International Religious Freedom Report 2007: Guyana | publisher = The Office of Electronic Information, Bureau of Public Affair | url =https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90256.htm | accessdate = 2009-09-05}} === Demographics === Bahá'ís sources state there were 110 members in 1969 and that by 1989 there were 22,000 (with 11,000 joining the religion in a three-month period in 1989.){{cite magazine | title = On cutting edge of 'entry by troops' |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1990 | number = 709 |ISSN=0195-9212 | page =8 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} C. 1990–1996 there are claims of the Bahá'ís population being over 5% of the population.{{cite journal | first = Stockman | last = Robert H. | first2 = Jonah | last2 = Winters | title = The Bahá'í Faith - A Short Introduction | booktitle = A Resource Guide for the Scholarly Study of the Bahá'í Faith | publisher = Research Office of the Bahá'í National Center of the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United States | year = 1997 | location = | url =http://bahai-library.com/books/rg/rg.curricula.html | doi = | id = | accessdate = 2009-09-05}}{{cite web | last = Universal House of Justice | first = | authorlink = Universal House of Justice | title = Ridván Letter, 1992 | work = Ridvan Messages from the Universal House of Justice | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | year = 1992 | url = http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ridvan_1992 | accessdate = 2009-08-30}} Large migrations, including many Bahá'ís, left Guyana for other places, especially New York and Toronto. By the time of the 2002 national census the Bahá'í population had ebbed to about 0.1%, or 500, Bahá'ís mostly in [[Regions of Guyana|Regions]] 3, 4, and 6 though Bahá'ís were noted in every Region. However, by 2005 the [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying mostly on the [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]) estimated some 13,000 Bahá'ís. More recently the National Assembly mentioned adding assemblies in [[Lethem, Guyana|Lethem]], [[Corentyne]] and [[Essequibo (colony)|Essequibo]]. Bahá'ís are now widely distributed across Guyana and represent all major racial groups and regions. The Bahá'í community, while relatively small, is well known for its emphasis on unity, non-involvement in politics and its work in issues such as literacy and youth issues. == See also == * [[Religion in Guyana]] * [[History of Guyana]] * [[Bahá'í Faith in Suriname]] * [[Bahá'í Faith in French Guiana]] == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [http://www.gy.bahai.org/ Official Webpage of the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Guyana] {{Latin America and the Caribbean topic|Bahá'í Faith in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baha'i Faith In Guyana}} [[Category:Religion in Guyana]] [[Category:Bahá'í Faith by country|Guyana]] [[Category:Bahá'í Faith in South America|Guy]]

{{Bahá'í sidebar}} The '''Bahá'í Faith in Portugal''' comes after the first mention of Portugal in [[Bahá'í literature]] when [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] mentioned it as a place to take the religion to in 1916.{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |origyear = 1916-17 |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-6.html |page=43}} The first Bahá'í visitor to Portugal was in 1926.{{Cite news | last = Moreira | first = Rute | title = Comunidade Bahá'í em Portugal | newspaper = Correio da Manhã | date = 2001-01-13 | url =http://bahai-library.com/moreira_comuidade_bahai_portugal | accessdate = 2010-05-03}} Its first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] was elected in [[Lisbon]] in 1946. In 1962 the Portuguese Bahá'ís elected their first [[National Spiritual Assembly]].{{cite book | last = Smith | first = Peter | title = Bahá'ís in the West | publisher = Kalimat Press | year = 2004 | location = | pages = 22, 36–38 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=x7wyJdyE60oC&lpg=PA13&ots=30IlFSEoRt&pg=PA22#v=onepage&q&f=false| isbn = 978-1-890688-11-0}} In 1963 there were nine assemblies.{{cite web | url =http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63&chapter=1#19 | title = The Bahá'í Faith: 1844-1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953-1963| author = Compiled by [[Hands of the Cause]] Residing in the Holy Land |page=109}} According to recent counts there are close to some 2000 members of the [[Bahá'í Faith]] in 2005 according to the [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying on [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]).{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2010-05-03| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100414021730/http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp| archivedate= 14 April 2010 | deadurl= no}} ==Early phase== ===`Abdu'l-Bahá's Tablets of the Divine Plan=== In the history of the Bahá'í Faith the first mentions of Portugal start in the twentieth century. [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], the son of the founder of the religion, wrote a series of letters, or [[tablets (religious)|tablets]], to the followers of the religion in the [[United States]] in 1916-1917; these letters were compiled together in the book titled [[Tablets of the Divine Plan]]. The seventh of the tablets was the first to mention several countries in [[Europe]] including beyond where `Abdu'l-Bahá had visited in 1911-12. Written on April 11, 1916, it was delayed in being presented in the United States until 1919 — after the end of [[World War I]] and the [[Spanish flu]]. The seventh tablet was translated and presented by [[Mirza Ahmad Sohrab]] on April 4, 1919, and published in [[Star of the West (Bahá'í magazine)|Star of the West]] magazine on December 12, 1919.{{cite book| last = Abbas | first = 'Abdu'l-Bahá |others=Mirza Ahmad Sohrab (trans. and comments) | title = Tablets, Instructions and Words of Explanation |date=April 1919 | url =http://bahai-library.com/abdulbaha_tablets_instructions_explanation}}
"In all the countries of the world the longing for universal peace is taking possession of the consciousness of men. … A most wonderful state of receptivity is being realized.… Therefore, O ye believers of God! Show ye an effort and after this war spread ye the synopsis of the divine teachings in the British Isles, France, Germany, Austria-Hungary, Russia, Italy, Spain, Belgium, Switzerland, Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Holland, Portugal, Rumania, Serbia, Montenegro, Bulgaria, Greece, Andorra, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Monaco, San Marino, Balearic Isles, Corsica, Sardinia, Sicily, Crete, Malta, Iceland, Faroe Islands, Shetland Islands, Hebrides and Orkney Islands."
===First contact=== [[Martha Root]] was an early traveler of the religion to visit Portugal in between 1923 and 1933.{{Cite thesis|last=Yang |first=Jiling |editor-last=Fletcher |editor-first=Ian |title=In Search of Martha Root: An American Bahá'í Feminist and Peace Advocate in the Early Twentieth Century |journal=Master's Thesis |publisher=Georgia State University, College of Arts and Sciences, Department of Women's Studies |date=2005-08-16 |url=http://etd.gsu.edu/theses/available/etd-11282005-004146/unrestricted/yang_jiling_200512_master.pdf |issn= |accessdate=2010-05-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091115023043/http://etd.gsu.edu/theses/available/etd-11282005-004146/unrestricted/yang_jiling_200512_master.pdf |archivedate=2009-11-15 |df= }} It is known that two Bahá'ís were interviewed by the newspapers ''Diario de Noticias'' and ''Diario de Lisboa'' and gave other talks on the religion in 1926. In 1946 the Bahá'í [[National Spiritual Assembly]] of the [[United States]] formed the Bahá'í European Teaching Committee to teach the religion in Europe. This endeavour oversaw the arrival of a number of Bahá'í [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]].{{cite encyclopedia| last = C. van den Hoonaard | first = Will| title = Netherlands | encyclopedia = draft of A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith | publisher = Baha'i Library Online | date = 1993-11-08 | url =http://bahai-library.com/hoonaard_encyclopedia_netherlands | accessdate = 2008-12-25}} Its first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] was elected in 1946 in Lisbon. Charlotte Stirratt was a pioneer who had moved to Lisbon, by November 1948. ==Growth== In September 1951 the first Iberian conference took place with nine native Bahá'ís and other pioneers who had attended the Fourth European Teaching Conference – recommendations from the consultation included exchanging updated information and further coordination between the communities, and to send contributions for the final work on the [[Shrine of the Báb]].{{cite magazine | title = First Iberian Conference|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1951 | number = 250 | page =9 | url =}} In 1953 [[Shoghi Effendi]], head of the religion after the death of [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], planned an international teaching plan termed the [[Ten Year Crusade]]. During the plan [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]] moved from Portugal colonies including [[Angola]] and [[East Timor]] from 1954.{{cite book | last = Vreeland | first = Claire | authorlink = |author2=Graham Hassall | title = And the trees clapped their hands : stories of Bahá'í pioneers | publisher = George Ronald | contribution = Harold and Florence Fitzner: Knights of Bahá'u'lláh to Portuguese Timor | contribution-url = http://bahai-library.com/hassall_fitzners_portuguese_timor | year = 1994 | location = Oxford, UK | pages = 320–332 | url = http://www.grbooks.com/show_book.php?book_id=4| isbn = 978-0-85398-378-1}} In 1957 Portugal and Spain formed a regional National Spiritual Assembly. The 1957 convention was witnessed by [[Charles Wolcott]] as a representative of Shoghi Effendi.{{cite magazine | title = We Look at Our Obiectives|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1957 | number = 316 | page =16 | url =}} In 1962 each formed their own independent [[National Spiritual Assembly]]. In 1963 the delegates to the national convention was set at 19.{{cite book |author = Rabbani, R. (Ed.) |authorlink = Rúhíyyih Khanum |year = 1992 |title = The Ministry of the Custodians 1957-1963 |publisher = Bahá'í World Centre |isbn = 0-85398-350-X | pages = 403, 412 |url = http://bahai-library.com/uhj_ministry_custodians}} In 1963, the members of the national assemblies of the world were the delegates to elect the [[Universal House of Justice]] for the first time - the members of the assembly of Portugal that participated were Angelo da Silva Carneiro, Mr. Mansour Masrour, Sara Tiffon Ramonet, Hilda Xavier Rodrigues, Carlos Salomao, Carl Scherer, Juliao Serrano, Celestino M. Silva and Richard Walters. In 1963 the community of Bahá'ís was organized into Assemblies, groups between 1 and 9 and isolated Bahá'is as follows: {| class="wikitable" |- | Assemblies | [[Almada]] | [[Espinho, Portugal|Espinho]] | [[Faro, Portugal|Faro]] | [[Lisbon]] |[[Oeiras Municipality, Portugal|Oeiras]]/[[Amadora]] | [[Portimão]] | [[Porto]] | [[Sintra]] | [[Trafaria]] |- | Groups between 1 and 9 adults | [[Barreiro (city)|Barreiro]] | [[Cascais]] | [[Charneca]] |- |Isolated Bahá'ís | [[Beja (Portugal)|Beja]] | [[Costa da Caparica]] | [[Monte da Caparica]] |[[Seixal Municipality|Seixal]]/[[Amora (Seixal)|Amora]] |} Despite this growth the government of Portugal actively opposed the development of the religion until liberalized following the [[Carnation Revolution]] of 1974 and the writing of the [[Portuguese Constitution of 1976]]. In 1987 the Portuguese community had 25 [[Local Spiritual Assembly|Local Spiritual Assemblies]] - more per capita than neighbouring Spain. The Portuguese Bahá'í Summer Schools are a series of annual events held in Portugal, as part of the "Summer School" concept of [[Bahá'í school]]. The Portuguese Bahá'í Summer Schools modestly emerged in the 60's, and have been growing in popularity and scope since. In 2009, the event hosted over 200 participants from all 5 continents, and counted with [[Ali Nakhjavani]] and Violette Nakhjavani, as well as [[Glenford Mitchell]], as main speakers.{{Cite web | title = Media (Pics & Vids) | work = | publisher = Summer School Committee | year = 2010| url = http://portuguesebahaisummerschool.com/m/Media-Pics-Vids- | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100823203220/http://www.portuguesebahaisummerschool.com/ | archivedate = August 23, 2010 | accessdate = 2010-10-17}} ==Modern community== There has been news coverage of the development of the [[Terraces (Bahá'í)|Bahá'í Terraced gardens]] in Haifa.{{Cite news | last = Marujo | first = Antonio | title = Os Novos Jardins Suspensos do Monte Carmelo Baha'ís inauguram espaço verde em Haifa | newspaper = Jornal Publico | date = 2001-05-23 | url = http://bahai-library.com/marujo_novos_jardins_suspensos | accessdate = 2010-05-03}} Recent counts show close to some 1,995 members of the [[Bahá'í Faith]] in 2005 according to the [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying on [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]). In 2007 the Bahá'ís of Portugal contributed to a religious discussion on society with the theme "The Baha'i faith and equal opportunities".{{Cite web|title=Diversidade e Igualdade de Oportunidades: Debates sobre Religião e Imigração |work=Eventos e Iniciativas |publisher=The Immigration Observatory (Government of Portugal) |year=2007 |url=http://www.oi.acidi.gov.pt/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1487 |accessdate=2010-05-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006205609/http://www.oi.acidi.gov.pt/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1487 |archivedate=2011-10-06 |df= }} In 2010 Marco Antonio Oliveira, a representative of the Bahá'í community of Portugal, was appointed by the Ministers of Justice and Parliamentary Affairs as a member of the Committee Issue of Time for Religions.{{Cite news | title = Novo membro na Comissão do Tempo de Emissão das Confissões Religiosas | newspaper = Agência Ecclesia | publisher = Comunicações Sociais | date = 2010-04-30 | url = http://www.agencia.ecclesia.pt/cgi-bin/noticia.pl?&id=79242 | accessdate = 2010-05-03}} ==See also== *[[History of Portugal]] *[[Religion in Portugal]] ==External links== *[http://www.bahai.pt/ Official Website of the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Portugal] Comunidade Bahá'í de Portugal **[https://bahaisdamadeira.no.sapo.pt/ Jornal Digital Baha'i da Madeira] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Europe topic|Bahá'í Faith in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baha'i Faith in Portugal}} [[Category:Bahá'í Faith in Portugal]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=October 2018}} [[File:StateLibQld 1 103873 Beatrice Grimshaw, author.jpg|thumb|Beatrice Grimshaw (1907)]] '''Beatrice Ethel Grimshaw''' (3 February 1870 – 30 June 1953) was a writer and traveller of [[Irish people|Irish]] origin, for many years based in [[Papua New Guinea]].
==Life== She was born in Cloona House<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.iguidez.com/video/guides/belfast/cloona-house-oasis-center/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2012-04-28 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120903200142/http://www.iguidez.com/video/guides/belfast/cloona-house-oasis-center/ |archive-date=2012-09-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> in [[Dunmurry]], [[County Antrim]], Ireland into a well-to-do family. She was educated privately, at [[Victoria College, Belfast]], in [[Caen]], France, then [[Bedford College (London)|Bedford College, London]] and [[Queen's College, Belfast]] and never graduated,<ref name=adb>{{cite book|url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/grimshaw-beatrice-ethel-6494/text11135|title=Australian Dictionary of Biography|first=Hugh|last=Laracy|publisher=National Centre of Biography, Australian National University|accessdate=8 October 2018|via=Australian Dictionary of Biography}}</ref> though it was later claimed she had been a lecturer in [[Classics]] at [[Bedford College (London)|Bedford Women's College]].<ref name=bg>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article22615642 |title=Beatrice Grimshaw |newspaper=[[The Queenslander]] |date=22 October 1921 |accessdate=28 April 2012 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Her family were members of the [[Church of Ireland]], but she converted to Catholicism after leaving home.
She worked for various shipping companies and then as a freelance journalist in Dublin. At the height of the [[Bike_boom#1890s|Bicycle Craze]] she contacted [[Richard J. Mecredy]], the proprietor of the Dublin-based ''Irish Cyclist'', expressing her interest in cycling and journalism. in 1891 she became a contributor to the magazine and two years later she became sub-editor. She then took over the magazine's sister publication, the ''Social Review'', which she edited until 1903.<ref>{{cite book | title=Isles of Adventure | publisher=Herbert Jenkins | author=Grimshaw, Beatrice | year=1930 | location=London}}</ref> But she had long harboured a desire to see the Pacific, and in 1904 she was engaged by the (London) ''Daily Graphic'' to report on the Pacific islands,<ref name=adb/> reportedly sailing around the Pacific islands in her own [[cutter (boat)|cutter]].<ref name=bg/> She was commissioned to write publicity for [[Cook Islands]], [[Fiji]], [[Niue]], [[Samoa]], and [[Tonga]].<ref name=adb/> In 1907 she sailed to [[Papua (Australian territory)|Papua]] on a commission from [[The Times]] and the [[Sydney Morning Herald]],<ref name=adb/> but remained for twenty-seven years, much of the time at [[Rona Falls]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article40502011 |title=Miss Beatrice Grimshaw |newspaper=[[The Cairns Post]] |location=Qld. |date=25 June 1925 |accessdate=29 April 2012 |page=4 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>Duncan, Joyce. 2002. ''Ahead of Their Time: A Biographical Dictionary of Risk-taking Women'', pp. 171-172. Greenwood Publishing Group.</ref> She became a close friend of [[Hubert Murray|Sir Hubert Murray]] and his unofficial publicist. She joined exploration parties and managed plantations, including one with her brother Ramsay.<ref name=adb/>
She also corresponded with Alfred Deakin- Australia's second, fifth and seventh Prime Minister regarding her work in the pacific.
In 1936, in company with brothers Ramsay and Osborne<ref name="adb" /> she retired to [[Kelso, New South Wales]], where she remained for the rest of her life.
==Films== *''[[The Adorable Outcast]]'' (1928) was based on her 1922 novel ''Conn of the Coral Seas'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1029820/|title=Beatrice Grimshaw|website=IMDb.com|accessdate=8 October 2018}}</ref>
==Publications== She wrote some 46 books, all out of print, including: *''Broken Away'' (1897)<ref name=adb/> *''Vaiti of the Islands'' (1907) a novel *''From Fiji to the Cannibal Islands'' (1907) *''In the Strange South Seas'' (1908) *''The New New Guinea'' (1910) *''When the Red Gods Call'' (1911) her best known novel *''The Sorcerer's Stone'' (1914) (ASIN: B009NNHHTM) *''Coral Queen'' (1919) *''White Savage Simon'' (1919) *''Queen Vaiti'' [[New South Wales Bookstall Co.]] Ltd., 1920 *''The Little Red Speck'' (short stories) Hurst and Blackett, Ltd., Melbourne, 1922<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27428734 |title=Beatrice Grimshaw |newspaper=[[The Queenslander]] |date=4 March 1922 |accessdate=28 April 2012 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> *''The Sands of Oro'' (1923) *''Conn of the Coral Seas'' Hurst and Blackett, Ltd., Melbourne, 1922<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27433816 |title=Beatrice Grimshaw |newspaper=[[The Queenslander]] |date=29 July 1922 |accessdate=28 April 2012 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> *''The Candles of Katara'' (1925 short stories)<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article25104400 |title=Beatrice Grimshaw |newspaper=[[The Queenslander]] |date=18 July 1925 |accessdate=28 April 2012 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> *''Isles of Adventure'' (1930) about her own travels
==Sources== *''The Oxford Companion to Australian Literature'' (2nd ed.) Oxford University Press, Melbourne 1994
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Beatrice Grimshaw}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Beatrice Ethel Grimshaw}} * {{FadedPage|id=Grimshaw, Beatrice|name=Beatrice Grimshaw|author=yes}} *[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/246276/Beatrice-Grimshaw Britannica Online Encyclopedia] *[http://www.grimshaworigin.org/WebPages/BeatGrim1.htm Beatrice Grimshaw, South Pacific Adventurer, Travel Writer and Novelist] *[http://grimshaworigin.org/prominent-grimshaw-individuals/beatrice-grimshaw-evaluations/ Evaluations of the Work of Beatrice Grimshaw by Academic Analysts] *[http://nla.gov.au/nla.obj-225220821/findingaid#2b41bda6ccd825d9a20675f0f6675d15 7 Letters to Alfred Deakin - Australian Prime Minister] *[http://www.westernadvocate.com.au/story/4645164/memorial-gets-new-inductees-photos/ Plaque honoring Grimshaw in Bathhurst, Australia] {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Grimshaw, Beatrice}} [[Category:1870 births]] [[Category:1953 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century Irish novelists]] [[Category:19th-century Irish women writers]] [[Category:19th-century Irish writers]] [[Category:20th-century Irish women writers]] [[Category:20th-century Irish writers]] [[Category:20th-century Irish novelists]] [[Category:Alumni of Bedford College (London)]] [[Category:Converts to Roman Catholicism from Anglicanism]] [[Category:Irish travel writers]] [[Category:Irish women journalists]] [[Category:Irish women novelists]] [[Category:Irish emigrants to Papua New Guinea]] [[Category:Papua New Guinean novelists]] [[Category:Papua New Guinean women writers]] [[Category:People from County Antrim]] [[Category:Roman Catholic writers]] [[Category:Women travel writers]]
