revision.comment: Reverted to revision 793067284 by [[Special:Contributions/212.139.209.172|212.139.209.172]] ([[User talk:212.139.209.172|talk]]): Not appropriate in a secular encyclopedia, ok for a Christian one. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
[[File:Meister des Rabula-Evangeliums 002.jpg|thumb|Stephaton, to the right of Jesus, in the earliest crucifixion in an [[illuminated manuscript]], from the [[Syriac language|Syriac]] [[Rabbula Gospels]], 586. Unlike [[Saint Longinus|Longinus]], he is not named here]]
'''Stephaton''', or '''Steven''', is the name given in medieval [[Christianity|Christian]] traditions to the [[Roman Empire|Roman]] soldier, [[list of names for the Biblical nameless|unnamed in the Bible]], who offered [[Jesus in Christianity|Jesus]] a sponge soaked in [[vinegar]] wine at the [[Crucifixion of Jesus|Crucifixion]]. In later depictions of the Crucifixion, Stephaton is frequently portrayed with [[Saint Longinus|Longinus]], the name given to the soldier who pierced Jesus' side with a spear.
==Gospel accounts== The account of [[Jesus]] receiving a sponge soaked in vinegar while on the cross appears in all four of the [[canonical gospels]], with some variation. In both {{bibleref|Mark|15:35-36}} and {{bibleref|Matthew|27:47-48}}, just after Jesus says "My God, my God, why have you forsaken me", a stander by soaks a sponge in vinegar and raises it on a reed for Jesus to drink. {{bibleref|Luke|23:36-37}} mentions that the attendant soldiers offer Jesus vinegar while mocking him – moving the mocking motif that occurs earlier in Mark and Matthew to the Crucifixion.<ref name=Luke>Johnson, Luke Timothy, and Daniel J. Harrington (1991) [https://books.google.com/books?id=eum1ijxbr6kC&pg=PA377&dq=Jesus+vinegar+Gospel+of+Luke&hl=en&ei=mkbiTuyQBMbqtge8rbCoBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=vinegar&f=false ''The Gospel of Luke''], p. 375 and note. Liturgical Press.</ref> In {{bibleref|John|19:28-30}}, Jesus declares "I thirst" (one of his [[Sayings of Jesus on the cross|last words]]) and is given the vinegar-soaked sponge "on [[ezov|hyssop]]".<ref name=John>Moloney, Francis J., and Daniel J. Harrington (1998). [https://books.google.com/books?id=2xDRFYKldboC&pg=PA501&dq=Jesus+%22I+thirst%22+crucifixion&hl=en&ei=gTniTv3nA4abtwfNzr35BA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CEgQ6AEwAw#v=snippet&q=%22I%20thirst%22&f=false ''The Gospel of John''], p. 501 and note. Liturgical Press.</ref> The significance of the act is unclear, though it is usually interpreted as an act of mercy on the part of the soldiers. The episode may allude to Psalm 68:22: "In my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink."<ref name=Luke/>
==In art== The soldier who offered Jesus the sponge is often paired with [[Saint Longinus|Longinus]], the name later given to the unnamed soldier who pierced Christ's side with a spear during the Crucifixion. It is not known when or how the name "Stephaton" originated for this character, though it had become common well before the end of the first millennium.<ref>Schiller, 93-94</ref>
In an iconographic tradition originating in [[Byzantine art]], and continuing in [[Carolingian art|Carolingian]] and [[Ottonian art]],<ref>Schiller, 93-94, 101, 105 </ref> in [[Crucifixion in the arts|depictions of the Crucifixion]], he was regularly shown alongside Longinus, with their actions shown simultaneously, though in the Biblical narrative, these took place at different times (Stephaton's occurs before Jesus' death, Longinus' occurred after.) This is also seen in [[Irish art]]<ref>Schiller, 102-103; [https://books.google.com/books?id=PggIclfQfx0C&pg=PA86&lpg=PA86]</ref> Colum Hourihane and others suggest the images should not be read as a simple narrative, but rather a mix of symbolism and representation typical of medieval art.<ref>Schiller, 93-94; [https://books.google.com/books?id=PggIclfQfx0C&pg=PA86&lpg=PA86]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
*Schiller, Gertrud, ''Iconography of Christian Art, Vol. II'', 1972 (English trans from German), Lund Humphries, London, {{ISBN|0-85331-324-5}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Stephaton}} [[Category:Christian hagiography]] [[Category:Christian mythology]] [[Category:People in the canonical gospels]] [[Category:1st-century deaths]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]]

{{short description|Ancient temple to the Phoenician god of healing in Lebanon}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox Historic Site |name=Eshmun Temple |native_name=معبد أشمون |native_language = Arabic |image=Throne of Ashtart.jpg |caption=Throne of [[Astarte]] at the Eshmun Temple |built_for =healing God of Sidon, [[Eshmun]] |architecture =[[Phoenicia]]n, [[Achaemenid Empire|Achaemenid]], [[Hellenistic period|Hellenistic]] and [[Roman Empire|Roman]] |governing_body =Directorate General of Antiquities<ref>{{Cite web|last = Lebanese Ministry of Culture|title = Ministère de la Culture|format = ministerial|accessdate = 2009-09-23|url = http://culture.gov.lb/Sections/main.ASP?page=Archeologie|language=fr}}</ref> |designation1= |designation1_date= |designation1_parent= |designation1_number= |designation1_criteria= |designation1_offname= |designation1_type=Cultural |designation1_free1name= |designation1_free1value= |designation2= |designation2_date= |designation2_number= |designation2_offname= |location=Bustan el-Sheikh, near [[Sidon]], Lebanon |built=7th century BC |architect= |coordinates = {{coord|33.58573|35.398204|display=inline,title}} |locmapin=Lebanon }}
The '''Temple of Eshmun''' ({{lang-ar|معبد أشمون}}) is an ancient [[place of worship]] dedicated to [[Eshmun]], the [[Phoenicia]]n god of healing. It is located near the [[Awali (river)|Awali river]], {{convert|2|km|mi}} northeast of [[Sidon]] in southwestern [[Lebanon]]. The site was occupied from the 7th century BC to the 8th century AD, suggesting an integrated relationship with the nearby city of Sidon. Although originally constructed by Sidonian king [[Eshmunazar II sarcophagus|Eshmunazar II]] in the [[Achaemenid Empire|Achaemenid era]] ({{circa}} 529–333 BC) to celebrate the city's recovered wealth and stature, the temple complex was greatly expanded by [[Bodashtart]], [[Yatan-milk]] and later monarchs. Because the continued expansion spanned many centuries of alternating independence and foreign [[hegemony]], the sanctuary features a wealth of different architectural and decorative styles and influences.
The sanctuary consists of an [[esplanade]] and a grand court limited by a huge [[limestone]] terrace wall that supports a monumental [[podium]] which was once topped by Eshmun's Graeco-Persian style [[marble]] temple. The sanctuary features a series of ritual [[Ritual purification|ablution]] basins fed by canals channeling water from the Asclepius river (modern [[Awali (river)|Awali]]) and from the sacred "Ydll" spring;<ref group="nb">The Phoenicians did not mark [[vowel]]s at all until the [[Punics]] fitfully added a system of [[mater lectionis|matres lectionis]] (vowel letters); for this reason the Phoenician inscription "Ydll" may be transcribed with a number of variant spellings (Yidlal, Yadlol etc.) Franz L. Benz (1982). ''Personal Names in the Phoenician and Punic Inscriptions''. Pontificio Istituto Biblico. p199, {{ISBN|978-8-876-53427-0}}.</ref> these installations were used for therapeutic and purificatory purposes that characterize the cult of Eshmun. The sanctuary site has yielded many artifacts of value, especially those inscribed with [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician texts]], providing valuable insight into the site's history and that of ancient Sidon.
The Eshmun Temple was improved during the early [[Roman Empire]] with a colonnade street, but declined after earthquakes and fell into oblivion as [[Early Christianity|Christianity]] replaced [[paganism]] and its large limestone blocks were used to build later structures. The temple site was rediscovered in 1900 by local [[Treasure hunting|treasure hunters]] who stirred the curiosity of international scholars. [[Maurice Dunand]], a French archaeologist, thoroughly excavated the site from 1963 until the beginning of the [[Lebanese Civil War]] in 1975. After the end of the hostilities and the retreat of [[Israel]] from [[Southern Lebanon]], the site was rehabilitated and inscribed to the [[World Heritage Site]] tentative list.
==Eshmun== {{Main article|Eshmun|Ancient Canaanite religion}} Eshmun was the Phoenician god of healing and renewal of life; he was one of the most important divinities of the [[Ancient Canaanite religion|Phoenician pantheon]] and the main male divinity of [[Sidon]]. Originally a nature divinity, and a god of spring vegetation, Eshmun was equated to [[Babylonia]]n deity [[Tammuz (deity)|Tammuz]]. His role later expanded within the Phoenician pantheon, and he gained celestial and cosmic attributes.<ref name="JWA">{{Cite book|publisher = Kessinger Publishing|isbn=978-0-766-17671-3|pages = 136–140|last = Jayne|first = Walter Addison| title = Healing Gods of Ancient Civilizations|year = 2003}}</ref>
The myth of Eshmun was related by the sixth century Syrian [[Neoplatonism|Neoplatonist philosopher]] [[Damascius]] and ninth century [[Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople|Patriarch of Constantinople]], [[Photios I of Constantinople|Photius]]. They recount that Eshmun, a young man from [[Beirut]], was hunting in the woods when [[Astarte]] saw him and was stricken by his beauty. She harassed him with her amorous pursuit until he [[Emasculation|emasculated]] himself with an [[axe]] and died. The grieving goddess revived Eshmun and transported him to the heavens where she made him into a god of [[heaven]].<ref group="nb">in [[Damascius]]'s ''Life of Isidore'' and Photius's ''Bibliotheca Codex 242''</ref><ref name = "wmb"/>
From a historical perspective, the first written mention of Eshmun goes back to 754 BC, the date of the signing of the treaty between [[Assyria]]n king [[Ashur-nirari V]] and Mati'el, king of [[Arpad, Syria|Arpad]]; Eshmun figures in the text as a patron of the treaty.<ref name="ddup"/>
Eshmun was identified with [[Asclepius]] as a result of the Hellenic influence over Phoenicia; the earliest evidence of this equation is given by coins from [[Amrit]] and [[Acre, Israel|Acre]] from the third century BC. This fact is exemplified by the Hellenized names of the [[Awali (river)|Awali]] river which was dubbed ''Asclepius fluvius'', and the Eshmun Temple's surrounding groves, known as the groves of Asclepius.<ref name= "JWA" />
==History== [[File:Echnoum Libanon 026.jpg|thumb|270px|alt= A wall made at its lower part of tightly packed white limestone stone blocks surmounted by a wall constructed of very large rusticated ashlar.|The ashlar podium at the [[Eshmun]] temple, Bustan el-Sheikh (near Sidon)]]
===Historical background=== In the 9th century BC, the [[Assyria]]n king [[Ashurnasirpal II]] conquered [[Mount Lebanon|the Lebanon]] mountain range and its coastal cities. The new sovereigns exacted tribute from Sidon, along with every other [[Phoenicia]]n city. These payments stimulated Sidon's search for new means of provisioning and furthered Phoenician emigration and expansion, which peaked in the 8th century BC.<ref name="ddup"/> When Assyrian king [[Sargon II]] died in 705 BC, the Sidonian king [[Luli]] joined with the [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptians]] and [[Kingdom of Judah|Judah]] in an unsuccessful rebellion against Assyrian rule,<ref name="teoh">{{Cite book|edition = 6, illustrated|publisher = Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|isbn = 978-0-395-65237-4|page = 36|last = Stearns|first = Peter|authorlink = Peter Stearns|author2=William Leonard Langer |title = The Encyclopedia of world history: ancient, medieval, and modern, chronologically arranged|year = 2001}}</ref> but was forced to flee to [[Kition]] (modern [[Larnaca]] in Cyprus) with the arrival of the Assyrian army headed by [[Sennacherib]], Sargon II's son and successor. Sennacherib instated [[Ittobaal]] on the throne of Sidon and reimposed the annual tribute.<ref name="teoh"/> When [[Abdi-Milkutti]] ascended to Sidon's throne in 680 BC, he also rebelled against the Assyrians. In response, the Assyrian king [[Esarhaddon]] laid siege to the city. Abdi-Milkutti was captured and beheaded in 677 BC after a three-year siege, while his city was destroyed and renamed Kar-Ashur-aha-iddina (the harbor of Esarhaddon). Sidon was stripped of its territory, which was awarded to [[Baal I]], the king of rival [[Tyre, Lebanon|Tyre]] and loyal [[vassal]] to Esarhaddon.<ref name="ddup"/><ref name="bible"/> Baal I and [[Esarhaddon's Treaty with Ba'al of Tyre|Esarhaddon signed a treaty]] in 675 in which Eshmun's name features as one of the deities invoked as guarantors of the covenant.<ref group="nb">Eshmun's name is transcribed in Akkadian as "''Ia-su-mu-nu''" in the Esarhaddon treaty</ref><ref name = "wmb">{{Cite book | publisher = Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing | isbn = 978-0-8028-2491-2 | pages = 306–309 | last = van der Toorn | first = K. | author2 = Bob Becking|author3=Pieter Willem van der Horst | title = Dictionary of deities and demons in the Bible DDD | year = 1999 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=yCkRz5pfxz0C&pg=PA307&dq=eshmun+esarhaddon+treaty&q=eshmun%20esarhaddon%20treaty }}</ref><ref name="fba">{{Cite conference |publisher = Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing|isbn = 978-0-8028-2173-7|conference = The future of biblical archaeology|page = 270|last = Hoffmeier|first = James Karl |author2=Alan Ralph Millard|title = The future of biblical archaeology: reassessing methodologies and assumptions|booktitle = The future of biblical archaeology: reassessing methodologies and assumptions: the proceedings of a symposium, August 12–14, 2001 at Trinity International University|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=PUcs-FQv4uIC&pg=PA270}}</ref>
===Construction=== Sidon returned to its former level of prosperity while Tyre was besieged for 13 years (586–573 BC) by the [[Chaldea]]n king [[Nebuchadnezzar II]].<ref name = "west">{{Cite book | edition = 2, illustrated, revised | publisher = Cambridge University Press|isbn = 978-0-521-79543-2|pages = 58–60|last = Aubet|first = María Eugenia|title = The Phoenicians and the West: politics, colonies and trade|year = 2001}}</ref> Nevertheless, the Sidonian king was still held in exile at the court of [[Babylon]].<ref name="ddup"/><ref name = "ANET" >{{Cite book|edition = 3| publisher = Princeton University Press|isbn = 978-0-8357-8801-4|last = Pritchard|first = James B.|title = Ancient Near Eastern Texts: Relating to the Old Testament|year = 1992}}</ref> Sidon reclaimed its former standing as Phoenicia's chief city in the [[Achaemenid Empire]] ({{circa}}529–333 BC). During this period, [[Xerxes I]] awarded king Eshmunazar II with the [[Sharon plain]]<ref group="nb">Territory south of Sidon from [[Mount Carmel]] to [[Jaffa]]</ref> for employing Sidon's fleet in his service during the [[Greco-Persian Wars]].<ref name="ddup"/><ref name = "ANET"/><ref name= "phoenician"/>
Eshmunazar II displayed his new-found wealth by constructing numerous temples to Sidonian divinities. Inscriptions found on the king's [[sarcophagus]] reveal that he and his mother, Amashtarte, built temples to the gods of Sidon,<ref name= "ddup"/> including the Temple of Eshmun by the "Ydll source near the cistern".<ref name="old">{{Cite book | edition = reprint | publisher = Ayer publishing | isbn = 978-0-8369-5771-6 | page = 137 | last = Hogarth | first = David George | authorlink = David George Hogarth |author2=Samuel Rolles Driver |title = Authority and archaeology, sacred and profane | year = 1971 }}</ref><ref name="cts">{{cite book | last = Curtis John| first = Sandra | authorlink = |author2=Nigel Tallis |author3=Béatrice André-Salvini | title = Forgotten Empire: The world of Ancient Persia| publisher =University of California Press | year = 2005 |page =42 | url = | isbn = 978-0-520-24731-4}}</ref>
As two series of inscriptions on the foundations of the monumental podium attest, construction of the sanctuary's podium did not begin until the reign of King [[Bodashtart]].<ref name="AIX">{{Cite journal | volume = 28 | issue = 121 | pages = 119–129 | last = Xella | first = Paola | author2 = José-Ángel Zamora López | author3=Astrid Nunn | title = L'inscription phénicienne de Bodashtart in situ à Bustān ēš-Šēẖ (Sidon) et son apport à l'histoire du sanctuaire | journal = Zeitschrift des Deutschen Palästina-Vereins|issn=0012-1169| accessdate = 2009-09-17 | year = 2005 | url = http://abstractairanica.revues.org/document16612.html|language=fr}}</ref> The first set of inscriptions bears the name of Bodashtart alone, while the second contains his name and that of the crown prince Yatan-milk.<ref name="ddup"/><ref name = "kings">{{Cite web| last = Elayi | first = Josette |publisher = digitorient.com| title = An updated chronology of the reigns of Phoenician kings during the Persian period (539–333 BC) |accessdate = 2009-09-05 | year = 2006 | url = http://www.digitorient.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/2006/10/2Updated%20Chronology1.pdf}}</ref> A Phoenician inscription, located {{convert|3|km|mi}} upstream from the temple, that dates to the 14th year of Bodashtart's reign, alludes to water adduction works from the Awali river to the "Ydll" source that was used for [[ritual purification]] at the temple.<ref name ="ddup"/><ref name="PX">{{Cite journal | volume = 28 | issue = 8 | pages = 273–300| last = Xella | first = Paola | author2 = José-Ángel Zamora López |author3=Astrid Nunn | title = Une nouvelle inscription de Bodashtart, roi de Sidon, sur la rive du Nahr al-Awwali près de Bustān ēš-Šēẖ | journal = Bulletin d'Archéologie et d'Architecture Libanaise |accessdate = 2009-09-17 | year = 2004 | url = http://abstractairanica.revues.org/document16652.html |language=fr}}</ref>
===Roman era and Decline=== The Eshmun sanctuary was damaged by an earthquake in the fourth century BC, which demolished the marble temple atop the podium; this structure was not rebuilt but many chapels and temples were later annexed at the base of the podium.<ref name = "paul"/><ref name = "NJ">{{Cite book | publisher = Dar el Mashreq | isbn = 978-0-71892-187-3 | last = Jidejian | first = Nina | title = Sidon, through the ages | year = 1971 |pages = 287}}</ref>
The temple site remained a place of pilgrimage in the [[classical antiquity]] during the early Roman Empire and until the advent of Christianity, when the cult of Eshmun was banned during the [[Persecution of pagans in the late Roman Empire]] and a Christian church was built at the temple site across the [[Roman roads|Roman street]] from the podium.<ref name = "NJ"/><ref name = "GB">{{Cite book| edition = illustrated | publisher = University of Michigan | isbn = 978-0-8109-0779-9 | last = Barraclough | first = Geoffrey | authorlink =Geoffrey Barraclough| title = The Christian world: a social and cultural history | year = 1981}}</ref> Remnants and mosaic floors of a [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] church can still be seen on the site.
A Roman colonnade was built in the third century, probably by emperor [[Septimius Severus]], and a Roman Villa showed a period of renewed relative importance for the city during the late period of [[Phoenicia under Roman rule]]. Furthermore, within the original Phoenician temple site the Romans added the processional stairway, the basins for ablutions and a [[nymphaeum]] with pictorial mosaics, that are still largely intact. Worn statuettes of three nymphs stand in the niches of a Roman fountain.<ref>[http://www.lebmania.com/about/photos/eshmoun/index.htm Roman Eshmoun: Roman Colonnade, villa & stairway with nimphaeum]</ref>
Another earthquake hit Sidon around 570 AD; [[Antoninus of Piacenza (pilgrim)|Antoninus of Piacenza]], an Italian Christian pilgrim, described the city as partly in ruins. For many years after the disappearance of the cult of Eshmun, the sanctuary site was used as a quarry:<ref name = "NJ"/> Emir [[Fakhr-al-Din II]], for example, used its massive blocks to build a bridge over the Awali river in the 17th century.<ref name = "SHMN"/>
The site later fell into oblivion until the 19th century<ref name = "NJ"/>
===Modern discovery=== [[File:Bodashtart 1.png|thumb|left|300px|alt= Phoenician writing from right to left. First line reads: Mēm Lāmedh Kaph Bēth Dāleth ʼAyin Šin Tāw Rēš Tāw Nun Bēth Nun ṣādē Dāleth Qōph Yōdh Tāw Nun Mēm Lāmedh Kaph Mēm Lāmedh Kaph ṣādē Dāleth Nun Mēm. Second line reads: Bēth Nun Bēth Nun Mēm Lāmedh Kaph ʼĀleph Šin Mēm Nun ʼAyin Zayin Rēš Mēm Lāmedh Kaph ṣādē Dāleth Nun Mēm ʼĀleph Yōdh Tāw Hē Bēth Tāw Zayin. Third line reads: Bēth Nun Lāmedh ʼĀleph Lāmedh Yōdh Lāmedh ʼĀleph Šin Mēm Nun Šin Rēš Qōph Dāleth Šin| [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] inscription of King Bodashtart found on the Eshmun Temple's podium. Bustan el-Sheikh, [[Sidon]], 4th century BC.<ref name = "syr"/>]] Between 1737 and 1742, [[Richard Pococke]], an English [[Anthropology|anthropologist]], toured the Middle East and wrote of what he thought were ruins of [[defensive wall]]s built with {{convert|3.7|m|ft|adj=on}} stone blocks near the Awali river. When the French [[Oriental studies|orientalist]] [[Ernest Renan]] visited the area in 1860, he noticed that the Awali bridge [[abutment]]s were built of finely [[Rustication (architecture)|rusticated]] blocks that originated from an earlier structure. He also noted in his report, [[Mission de Phénicie (1865–1874)|''Mission de Phénicie'']], that a local treasure hunter told him of a large edifice near the Awali bridge.<ref name = "syr">{{Cite journal | volume = 5 | issue = 5-1 | pages = 9–23 | last = Conteneau | first = Gaston | title = Deuxième mission archéologique à Sidon (1920) | journal = Syria | accessdate = 2009-08-31 | year = 1924 | url =http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/syria_0039-7946_1924_num_5_1_3094 | doi = 10.3406/syria.1924.3094|language=fr}}</ref>
In 1900, local clandestine treasure hunters digging at the Eshmun Temple site haphazardly discovered inscriptions carved onto the temple's walls. This discovery stirred the interest of Theodore Macridy, curator of the [[Istanbul Archaeology Museums|Museum of Constantinople]], who cleared the temple remains between 1901 and 1903.<ref name = "syr"/> Wilhelm Von Landau also excavated the site between 1903 and 1904.<ref name="ddup"/> In 1920, Gaston Contenau headed a team of archaeologists who surveyed the temple complex.<ref name= "syr"/> The first extensive archaeological excavation revealing the Eshmun Temple remains was undertaken by Maurice Dunand between 1963 and 1975.<ref name="ddup"/><ref name="poe"/> Archaeological evidence shows that the site was occupied from the seventh century BC to the eighth century AD.<ref name="MESu">{{Citation| publisher = UNESCO |author=Direction Générale des Antiquités, Ministère de la Culture et de l'Enseignement Supérieur | title =Monument: Temple d'Echmoun – UNESCO World Heritage Centre|url =http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/401/ |language=fr}}</ref>
===After 1975=== During the [[Lebanese Civil War]] and the [[South Lebanon conflict (1985–2000)|Israeli occupation of South Lebanon (1985–2000)]], the temple site was neglected and was invaded by vegetation overgrowth;<ref name="da">{{Cite book | publisher = Petit Futé | isbn = 978-2-7469-1632-6 | page = 12 | last = Auzias | first = Dominique | author2 = Jean-Paul Labourdette |author3=Guillaume Boudisseau|author4=Christelle Thomas | title = Le Petit Futé Liban | year = 2008 |language=fr}}</ref> it was cleared and recovered its former condition after the Israeli withdrawal. Today the Eshmun sanctuary can be visited all year round and free of charge, it is accessible from an [[Interchange (road)|exit ramp]] off the main Southern Lebanon highway near Sidon's northern entrance. The site holds a particular [[archaeology|archaeological]] importance since it is the best preserved Phoenician site in Lebanon;<ref name="CN">{{Cite book | publisher = Etudes et Consultations Economiques | page = 46 | last = Najjar | first = Charles |author2=Tyma Daoudy | title = The indispensable guide to Lebanon | year = 1999 }}</ref> it was added to the [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site|World Heritage]] Tentative List's Cultural category on {{Nowrap|July 1}}, 1996.<ref name="MESu"/>
In literature, the temple of Eshmun figures in Nabil Saleh's 2009 novel, ''The Curse of [[Ezekiel]]'' as the setting where Bomilcar falls in love and rescues princess Chiboulet from the evil design of one of the temple's priests.<ref name="novel">{{Cite book |publisher = Quartet books | isbn = 978-0-7043-7167-5 | last = Saleh | first = Nabil | title = The Curse of Ezekiel | year = 2009}}</ref>
==Location== A number of ancient texts mention the Eshmun Temple and its location. The [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] inscriptions on the [[sarcophagus]] of Eshmunazar II, a Sidonian king,<ref group="nb">Discovered by the general consulate of France in Beirut Aimé Pérétié in 1855 in the Magharet Adloun necropolis, now on display in the Louvre</ref> commemorate the construction of a "house" for the "holy prince" Eshmun by the king and his mother, queen Amashtart, at the "Ydll source by the cistern".<ref name="corpus">{{Cite book | edition = illustrated | publisher = Routledge | isbn = 978-0-415-43628-1 | page = 664 | last = Kuhrt |first = Amélie | title = The Persian Empire: A corpus of sources of the Achaemenid period | accessdate = 2009-08-28 | url =https://books.google.com/?id=XWbhmebyhxAC&pg=RA1-PA664&dq=eshmunazar+II+built&q=eshmunazar%20II%20built | year = 2007 }}</ref> [[Dionysius Periegetes]], an ancient [[Greeks|Greek]] [[travel writer]], identified the [[Eshmun]] temple by the Bostrenos River, and Antonin de Plaisance, a 6th-century AD [[Italians|Italian]] [[Christian pilgrimage|pilgrim]] recorded the shrine as near the river Asclepius fluvius.<ref name="ddup">{{Cite book | publisher = Peeters Publishers | isbn = 978-90-6831-690-2 | pages = 120–496 | last = Lipiński | first = Edward |authorlink = Edward Lipiński| title = Dieux et déesses de l'univers phénicien et punique | year = 1995 |language=fr}}</ref><ref name="saint">{{Cite book | publisher = EDITIONS CREER | isbn = 978-2-84819-041-9 | pages = 100–101 | last = Baudoin | first = Jacques | title = Grand livre des saints: culte et iconographie en Occident | year = 2006 |language=fr}}</ref><ref name="pilg">{{Cite book | publisher = The Newman Press | isbn = 978-0-8091-0029-3 | volume = 38 <!-- | pages = 287 --> | last = Gingras | first = George E. | title = Egeria: diary of a pilgrimage | series = Ancient Christian writers | year = 1970 }}</ref><ref name="dico">{{Cite book | publisher = Brepols | isbn = 978-2-503-50033-1 |last = Lipiński |first = Edward | author2 = [[Marcel Le Glay]]|author3=[[René Rebuffat]]|author4=Claude Domergue|author5=Marie-Hélène Marganne | title = Dictionnaire de la civilisation phénicienne et punique | year = 1996 <!-- | pages = 502 --> |language=fr}}</ref>[[Strabo]]<ref group="nb">In Strabo's "Geographica"</ref> and other Sidonian sources describe the sanctuary and its surrounding "sacred forests" of [[Asclepius]], the Hellenized name of Eshmun, in written texts.<ref name="ddup"/>
Located about {{convert|40|km|mi}} south of [[Beirut]] and {{convert|2|km|mi}} northeast of Sidon, the Eshmun Temple sits on the southern bank of the modern [[Awali (river)|Awali river]], previously referred to as Bostrenos or Asclepius fluvius in ancient text. Citrus groves, known as ''Bustan el-Sheikh'' ({{lang-ar|بستان الشيخ}}, the grove of the [[Sheikh]]), occupy the ancient "sacred forests" of Asclepius and are a favorite summer picnic location for locals.<ref name="ddup"/><ref name="sand">{{Cite book |edition = 3 | publisher = Lonely Planet | isbn = 978-1-74104-609-0 | pages = 370–371 | last = Carter | first = Terry |author2=Lara Dunston |author3=Amelia Thomas | title = Syria & Lebanon | year = 2008 }}</ref>
==Architecture and description== [[File:Eshmun - Sidon.jpg|thumb|left|alt= Two damaged white marble wheel like column bases lying in a yellow flower filled field. The front base shows finely carved intertwining circular decorations.|Spring flowers bloom near the base of a Babylonian-style column in Bustan el-Sheikh.]] Built under [[History of Lebanon under Babylonian rule|Babylonian rule]] (605–539 BC),<ref name="ddup"/> the oldest monument at the site is a [[pyramid]]al building resembling a [[ziggurat]] that includes an access ramp to a water cistern.<ref name="brl">{{Cite book | publisher = Brill Archive | isbn = 978-90-04-07091-2 | last = Wright | first = George R. H| title = Ancient building in south Syria and Palestine |pages=98–101}}</ref> Fragments of marble column bases with [[Torus]] moldings and facetted columns found east of the podium are also attributed to the Babylonian era.<ref name="basins"/>
The pyramidal structure was superimposed during [[History of Lebanon under Persian rule|Persian]] rule by a massive [[ashlar]] podium constructed from heavily bossed limestone blocks that measured more than {{convert|3|m|ft}} across by {{convert|1|m|ft}}thick, which were laid down in courses {{convert|1|m|ft|adj=on}} high. The podium stands {{convert|22|m|ft}} high, runs{{convert|50|m|ft}} into the hillside, and boasts a {{convert|70|m|ft|adj=on}} wide façade.<ref name= "phoenician">{{Cite book |edition = illustrated | publisher = University of California Press | isbn = 978-0-520-22614-2 | pages = 54–128 | last = Markoe | first = Glenn | title = Phoenicians | series = Peoples of the past | year = 2000 }}</ref><ref name ="brl"/> The terrace atop of the podium was once covered by a Greco-Persian style marble temple probably built by [[Ionia|Ionic]] artisans around 500 BC.<ref name="basins"/> The marble temple has been reduced to a few remaining stone fragments due to theft.<ref name="brl" />
During the [[Hellenistic period]], the sanctuary was extended from the base of the podium across the valley.<ref name="basins"/> To the east base of the podium stands a large chapel, {{convert|10.5|x|11.5|m|ft}}, dating to the 4th century BC.<ref name="poe"/><ref name="MJS">{{Cite book | publisher = Vision | isbn = 978-88-8162-141-5 | last = Strazzulla | first = M. José | title = Ancien Liban: les monuments autrefois et aujourd’hui | year = 2004 |language=fr}}</ref> The chapel was adorned with a paved pool and a large stone throne carved of a single block of [[granite]] in the Egyptian style;<ref name="ddup"/><ref name = "paul">{{Cite book |edition = illustrated | publisher = Wakefield Press | isbn = 978-1-86254-562-5 | pages = 200–202 | last = Lewis | first = Peter |author2=Ron Bolden | title = The pocket guide to Saint Paul: coins encountered by the apostle on his travels | year = 2002}}</ref><ref name="poe"/> it is flanked by two [[sphinx]] figures and surrounded by two lion sculptures. The throne, attributed to the Sidonian goddess [[Ashtart|Astarte]], rests against the chapel wall, which is embellished by relief sculptures of hunting scenes.<ref name="ddup"/><ref name="poe"/> The once important Astarte basin lost its function during the 2nd century AD and was filled with earth and statue fragments.<ref name="MJS"/> The west base contains another 4th-century BC chapel—centered on a bull [[protome]] topped [[Capital (architecture)|capital]]—that remains preserved at the [[National Museum of Beirut]].<ref name="ddup"/><ref name="poe"/><br/> <!-- ===Tribune of Eshmun===-->
Widely known as the "Tribune of Eshmun" because of its shape, the altar of Eshmun is a white marble structure dating to the 4th century BC. It is {{convert|2.15|m|ft}} long by {{convert|2.26|m|ft}} wide and {{convert|2.17|m|ft}} tall.<ref name="ddup"/><ref name="poe"/><ref name="CK"/> Unearthed in 1963 by Maurice Dunand, it stands on a [[limestone]] [[Socle (architecture)|socle]]plated with marble blocks that rest against a retaining wall<!-- for the temple's canalization -->.<ref name="sis">{{Cite book |edition = illustrated | publisher = University of Wisconsin Press | isbn = 978-0-299-15470-7 | first = Brunilde Sismondo | last = Ridgway |authorlink = Brunilde Sismondo Ridgway | title = Fourth-century styles in Greek sculpture | series = Wisconsin studies in classics | year = 1997<!-- | page = 480 --> }}</ref> The altar is adorned with [[Hellenistic art|Hellenistic style]] [[relief]] sculptures and is framed by decorative [[Molding (decorative)|moldings]],<ref name="ddup"/><ref name="poe"/> one of which divides the altar into two distinct [[Register (sculpture)|registers]] of symmetrical composition.<!-- each depicting [[Greek mythology|Greek mythological]] [[Greek_gods#Olympian_deities|personages]] --> The upper register portrays 18 Greek deities,<ref group="nb">The front register depicts from left to right: [[Eros]], an unidentified matronly goddess who stands behind [[Artemis]] who is crowning an enthroned [[Leto]]. [[Apollo]] stands, playing a cithara next to [[Athena]]. [[Zeus]] appears next, enthroned with [[Hera]] standing by his side followed by standing figures of [[Amphitrite]] and [[Poseidon]] who stands at the right corner, his foot resting on a rock. On the right short side, turning the corner from Eros, the standing figures and the charioteer are identified as [[Demeter]], [[Persephone]] and [[Helios]]. On the opposite short side, the three personages are assumed to be [[Dione (mythology)|Dione]], [[Aphrodite]] and [[Selene]] driving a [[quadriga]]. (from Brunilde Sismondo Ridgway's ''Fourth-century styles in Greek sculpture'')</ref> including two charioteers surrounding the Greek god [[Apollo]], who is depicted playing a [[cithara]] (a type of [[lyre]]). The lower register honors [[Dionysus]], who leads his ''[[Thiasus|thiasos]]'' (his ecstatic revenue) in a dance to the music of pipe and cithara players.<ref name="sis"/> The Tribune is displayed at the National Museum of Beirut.<ref name="nmb">{{Cite web | title = Collections – The Hellenistic period (333 BC – 64 BC) | publisher = Beirut National Museum | format = educational | accessdate = 2009-08-28 | url = http://www.beirutnationalmuseum.com/e-collection-hellenistique.htm | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090602124532/http://www.beirutnationalmuseum.com/e-collection-hellenistique.htm | archivedate = June 2, 2009 | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
Northeast of the site, another 3rd century BC temple stands adjacent to the Astarte chapel. Its {{convert|22|m|ft|adj=on}}façade is built with large limestone blocks and displays a two-register relief decoration illustrating a [[Bacchanalia|drunken revelry]] in honor of [[Dionysus]], the Greek god of wine. Among the temple reliefs, one shows a man attempting to seize a large rooster which was the common sacrificial animal for Eshmun-Asclepius.<ref name = "NJ"/><ref name = "hart">{{Cite book | edition = illustrated | publisher = RSM press | isbn = 978-1-85315-409-6 | page = 73 | last = Hart | first = Gerald David | title = Asclepius: the god of medicine | series = History of Medicine Series | year = 2000 }}</ref>
The Eshmun Temple complex comprises an elaborate [[Hydraulics|hydraulic installation]] channeling water from "Ydll" spring that is made up of an intricate system of water canals, a series of retaining basins, sacred ablution basins and paved pools. This system demonstrates the importance of ritual ablutions in Phoenician therapeutic cults.<ref name="basins">{{Cite book | edition = illustrated | publisher = I.B. Tauris | isbn = 978-1-85043-533-4 | pages = 129, 177 | last = Moscati | first = Sabatino|authorlink = Sabatino Moscati| title = The Phoenicians }}</ref>
Later vestiges date from the [[History of Lebanon under Roman rule|Roman epoch]] and include a colonnaded road lined with shops. Of the large marble columns bordering the Roman street only fragments and bases remain. The [[Ancient Rome|Romans]] also built a monumental staircase adorned with [[mosaic]] patterns that leads to the top of the podium. To the right of the Roman road, near the entrance of the site stands a [[nymphaeum]] with [[Niche (architecture)|niches]] where statues of the [[nymph]]s once stood. The floor of the nymphaeum is covered by a mosaic depicting the [[Maenads]]. Across the colonnaded road, facing the nymphaeum, are the ruins of a [[Roman villa]]; only the villa's courtyard has survived along with the remains of a mosaic depicting the [[Season|four seasons]]. To the right of the processional Roman staircase stands a cubic [[altar]], also of Roman construction. Other Roman period structures include two columns of a great portico leading to pools and other cultic installations.<ref name="ddup"/><ref name = "SHMN">{{Cite web | last = Lebanese Ministry of Tourism | title = Eshmoun – A unique Phoenician site in Lebanon | work = Lebmania | accessdate = 2009-09-04 | url = http://www.lebmania.com/about/photos/eshmoun/index.htm }}</ref><ref name = "SLH">{{Cite book | edition = illustrated | publisher = Footprint Travel Guides | isbn = 978-1-900949-90-3 | pages =542–543 | last = Mannheim |first = Ivan | title = Syria & Lebanon handbook | series = Footprint series | year = 2001 }}</ref>
==Function== Eshmun's cult enjoyed a particular importance at Sidon as he was the chief deity after 500 BC. Aside from the extramural sanctuary at Bustan el-Sheikh, Eshmun also had a temple within the city. The extramural Eshmun Temple was associated with purification and healing; ritual lustral ablutions were performed in the sanctuary's sacred basins supplemented by running water from the Asclepius River and the "Ydll" spring water which was considered to have a sacred character and therapeutic quality.<ref name = "wmb"/><ref name= "RR">{{Cite journal | issn = 1988-9100 | volume = 1 | pages = 21–40 | last = Rodriguez | first = Raquel |title = El uso cúltico del agua en el mundo fenicio y Púnico. El caso de astarté en cádiz | journal = Herakleion | accessdate = 2009-09-17 | year = 2008 | url = http://herakleion.es/raquel%20rodriguez.pdf |language=es}}</ref> The healing attributions of Eshmun were combined with his divine consort Astarte's [[fertility|fertilizing]] powers; the latter had an annex chapel with a sacred paved pool within the Eshmun sanctuary.<ref name="RR"/> Pilgrims from all over the ancient world flocked to the Eshmun Temple leaving [[Votive offering|votive]] traces of their devotion and proof of their cure.<ref name="MsO">{{Cite journal | volume = 32 | pages = 45–49 | last = Masson O. | title = Pélerins chypriotes en Phénicie (Sarepta et Sidon) | journal = Semitica Paris | year = 1982 |language=fr}}</ref><ref name = "Leb">{{Cite book | publisher = Macmillan | page = 137 |last = Hitti | first = Philip K. | title = Lebanon in History from the earliest times to the present| accessdate = 2009-09-01 |year = 1957 | url = https://www.questia.com/read/100122358?title=Lebanon%20in%20History%20from%20the%20Earliest%20Times%20to%20the%20Present# }}</ref> There is evidence that from the 3rd century BC onwards there have been attempts to Hellenize the cult of Eshmun and to associate him with his Greek counterpart Asclepius, but the sanctuary retained its curative function.<ref name="NJ4">{{Cite book | edition = 1 | publisher = Dar an-Nahar |isbn = 2-84289-344-1 <!-- | pages = 342 -->| last = Jidejian | first = Nina | title = Liban une mosaïque de cultures Lebanon a mosaic of cultures | year = 2001 }} {{fr icon}} {{en icon}}</ref>
==Artifacts and finds== [[File:Votive statue Eshmun.jpg|thumb|right|alt= Three-quarter view of a sculpture of a young child's head, the child appears smiling his face has relaxed expressions as he gazes over the viewer's shoulders |[[Votive offering|Votive]] marble head of a child found at the Eshmun Temple site; National Museum of Beirut collection, beginning of the 4th century BC<ref name="CK">{{Cite book |publisher = Anis commercial printing press | isbn = 9953-0-0038-7 | page = 96 | last = Charles Kettaneh Foundation |author2=Omar Daouk Foundation | title = A visit to the Museum... The short guide of the National Museum of Beirut, Lebanon|year = 2008}}</ref>]] Apart from the large decorative elements, carved friezes and mosaics which were left [[in situ]], many artifacts were recovered and moved from the Eshmun Temple to the [[National Museum of Beirut|national museum]], the [[Louvre]] or are in possession of the Lebanese directorate general of antiquities. Some of these smaller finds include a collection of inscribed [[ostracon|ostraca]] unearthed by Dunand providing rare examples of cursive Phoenician writing in the Phoenician mainland.<ref name="poe">{{Cite book |publisher = BRILL | isbn = 978-90-04-10068-8 | pages =21, 100–101, 120, 365, 460, 566–567, 617 | last = Krings | first = Veronique | title = La civilisation phénicienne et punique | accessdate = 2009-03-17 | year = 1995 | url =https://books.google.com/?id=tdPwhNHB3Z4C&pg=PA101&dq=temple+d%27eshmoun |language=fr}}</ref> One of the recovered ostracon bears the [[Theophoric name|theophoric]] Phoenician name "grtnt" which suggests that veneration of the lunar-goddess [[Tanit]] occurred in Sidon.<ref group="nb">Antoine Vanel, Six "ostraca" phéniciens trouvés dans le temple d'Echmoun, près de Saida, in [[National museum of beirut#Publications|Bulletin du Musée de Beyrouth]], 20, (1967), p.53</ref><ref name="leuven">{{Cite conference | publisher = Peeters Publishers | isbn = 978-90-6831-073-3 | volume = v.22 ''Orientalia Lovaniensia analecta'' | page = 81 | last = Lipiński | first = Edward | title = Phoenicia and the East Mediterranean in the first millennium BC |booktitle = proceedings of the conference held in Leuven from November 14 to 16, 1985 | year = 1985 }}</ref>
A number of fragmented votive life-size sculptures of little children lying on their side and holding a pet animal or a small object were also recovered at the temple site; among the best known of these is a sculpture of a royal child holding a dove with his right hand; the boy's head is shaved, his torso is bare and his lower body is wrapped in a large cloth. The socle of this sculpture is inscribed with a dedication from Baalshillem,<ref group="nb">The dedication reads: "This (is the) statue which Baalshillem son of King Ba'na, king of the Sidonians, son of King Abdamun, king of the Sidonians, son of King Baalshillem, king of the Sidonians, gave to his lord Eshmun at the "Ydll"-Spring. May he bless him" (taken from JCL Gibson's ''Textbook of Syrian Semitic inscriptions'')</ref><ref name="JCL">{{Cite book | publisher = Clarendon Press | isbn = 978-0-19-813199-1 | volume = 3 | last = Gibson | first = John Clark Love | title = Textbook of Syrian Semitic inscriptions | year = 1982 |page=115}}</ref> the son of a Sidonian king to Eshmun, which illustrates the importance of the site to the Sidonian monarchy.<ref name="bible">{{Cite book | edition = reprint, revised | publisher = Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing | isbn = 978-0-8028-3784-4 | volume = 4 | pages = 502, 934 | last = Bromiley | first = Geoffrey | title = The international standard Bible encyclopedia: Q-Z | series = The International Standard Bible Encyclopedia | year = 1995 }}</ref><ref name="poe"/><ref name = "Leb"/> These votive sculptures appear to have been purposely broken after dedication to Eshmun and then ceremoniously cast into the sacred canal, probably simulating the sacrifice of the sick child. All of these sculptures represent boys.<ref name="NJ4"/> A{{convert|31.5|x|27|cm|in|abbr=on}} limestone bust of a [[Kouros]] dating from the 6th century BC was found at the site, but unlike the archaic Greek kouroi this figure is not bare.<ref name = "CK"/>
Among the notable finds is a golden plaque showing [[Rod of Asclepius|a snake curling on a staff]], a Hellenic symbol of Eshmun.<ref name = "paul"/> and a [[granite]] [[altar]] bearing the name of [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptian]] [[Pharaoh]] [[Achoris]] uncovered in the Eshmun sanctuary. This gift attests to the good relations between the Pharaoh and the kings of Sidon.<ref name="DJ">{{Cite book | publisher = Continuum International Publishing Group | isbn = 978-1-84127-292-4 | volume = 350 |page = 124 | last = Janzen | first = David | title = Witch-hunts, purity and social boundaries: the expulsion of the foreign women in Ezra 9–10 | series = [[Journal for the study of the Old Testament]] | year = 2002 }}</ref><ref name="IP">{{Cite book | edition = illustrated | publisher = Peeters Publishers | isbn = 978-90-429-1344-8 | volume = 18 | page = 635 | last = Lipiński, Edward | title = Itineraria Phoenicia | series = Studia Phoenicia | year = 2004 }}</ref>
The repute of the sanctuary was far reaching. Cypriot pilgrims from [[Paphos]] left marks of their devotion for Astarte on a marble [[stele]] inscribed both in Greek and [[Cypriot syllabary]] at Astarte's shrine; this stele is now in the custody of the Lebanese directorate general of antiquities.<ref name="MsO"/>
==Pillaging== Treasure hunters have sought out the Eshmun Temple since antiquity;<ref name = "syr"/> around 1900 artifacts bearing Phoenician inscriptions from the temple site found their way to [[Beirut]]ine [[Antiquities trade|antiquities markets]] where they stirred the interest of the [[Ottoman empire|Ottoman]] authorities and prompted a series of archeological digs.<ref name="LOLJ">{{Cite news|edition = 12733|page = 4|last = Makarem| first = May|title = Qui est responsable du pillage du temple d'Echmoun – Six cent pièces issues du temple d'Echmoun circulent sur le marché mondial des antiquités|work = L'Orient-Le Jour|date = December 4, 2009|language=fr}}</ref> During the civil war, upon a request from then Lebanese director general of antiquities [[Maurice Chehab]], Maurice Dunand moved more than 2000 artifacts from Sidon to a subterranean chamber at the [[Byblos Castle|Byblos crusader castle]], {{convert|30|km|mi}} north of Beirut. In 1981, the depot was looted and around 600 sculptures and architectural elements were stolen and smuggled out of Lebanon. Rolf Stucky, ex-director of the Institute of Classical Archeology of [[Basel]] affirmed during a conference in Beirut in {{Nowrap|December 2009}} the successful identification and return of eight sculptures to the Lebanese national museum.<ref name="LOLJ"/>
==Notes== [[File:Votive statue from eshmun.jpg|thumb|right|240px|alt=Beige marble statue of a stout young child aged about two years old lying on his left side. The child's head is shaven, his eyes gaze over the viewer's shoulder and his lower body is covered in a draping cloth that hangs limply between his flexed feet. The child supports his torso with his left hand in which he holds an unidentifiable object, he also holds a small bird in his right hand. The sculpture rests on a heavy socle inscribed with barely visible letters spanning the upper part of the socle vertically. |Votive marble statue of a royal child, inscribed in Phoenician, from the [[Eshmun]] sanctuary, c. 400s BC]] <references group="nb"/> <!--{{coord|33|35|08.63|N|35|23|52.64|E|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=title}}-->

{{For|the [[Trinity Broadcasting Network|TBN]] series|Praise the Lord (TV program)}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox television | show_name = The PTL Club | image = | caption = | show_name_2 = The Jim and Tammy Show
PTL Today
Heritage Today | genre = [[Religious]] [[talk show]] | creator = [[Jim Bakker]] | developer = | writer = | director = | creative_director = | presenter = | starring = [[Jim Bakker]] & [[Tammy Faye Bakker]] (1974–1987)
Henry Harrison
[[Richard Dortch]]
[[Doug Oldham]]
Gary McSpadden
Ron Aldridge
Brenda Davis | judges = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 14 | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = | editor = | location = [[Charlotte, North Carolina]]
[[Fort Mill, South Carolina]] | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = 60 minutes | company = | distributor = | channel = [[PTL Satellite Network]], The Inspirational Network | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = 1974 | last_aired = 1989 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = ''[[The 700 Club]]'', ''[[Trinity Broadcasting Network|Praise The Lord]]'' | website = | website_title = | production_website = }} '''''The PTL Club''''' (PTL stands for "Praise The Lord" or "People That Love"), later called '''''The Jim and Tammy Show''''', and in its last days '''''PTL Today''''' and '''''Heritage Today''''', was a [[Christian]] television program first hosted by [[Evangelism|evangelist]]s [[Jim Bakker|Jim]] and [[Tammy Faye Bakker]], which ran from 1974 to 1989. ''The PTL Club'', which adopted a talk-show format, was the flagship television program of the Bakkers' [[PTL Satellite Network]]. == History == Jim Bakker and his wife Tammy had been in the ministry with the [[Assemblies of God]] since the early 1960s prior to joining [[Pat Robertson]]'s [[Christian Broadcasting Network]], then based in [[Portsmouth, Virginia]] in 1965. The Bakkers launched a children's show called ''Come On Over'' where the couple entertained viewers with songs, stories, and puppets. In 1966 Jim Bakker became the host of ''[[The 700 Club]]'', a religious talk program which evolved from a [[telethon]]. ''The 700 Club'' would become the flagship program of Christian Broadcasting Network, which expanded from its original [[WGNT|Hampton Roads]] station to include outlets in [[WGCL-TV|Atlanta]] and [[KXTX-TV|Dallas–Fort Worth]] by 1973. Beginning in 1972, ''The 700 Club'' was launched in a dozen test markets, including then-independent station [[WCNC-TV|WRET-TV]] in [[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]]. When station owner [[Ted Turner]] dropped the show from his station in 1974, Turner approached Bakker about buying two hours a day on his Charlotte station, which Bakker accepted. He opted to call the show ''The PTL Club'', and ''The 700 Club'' moved to then-ABC affiliate [[WCCB]] in Charlotte. The program began as a local TV broadcast in a small studio at WRET in November 1974. The show expanded to a few other stations early the next year, such as [[WGGS]] in [[Greenville, SC]], [[WHMB]] in [[Indianapolis]], [[WUVN|WHCT]] in [[Hartford, Connecticut]] and [[KPXN|KHOF]] in [[Los Angeles]], among a few others. The show launched nationally in the fall of 1975, with two editions offered: one was the full two-hour edition, which tended to air on Christian stations and smaller independent stations, and the other was a one-hour edition which tended to air on stronger independent stations, as well as network affiliates. By 1976, the Bakkers moved their studio to a former [[Charlotte, North Carolina]] furniture store. The show continued to be hosted by [[Jim Bakker]] and co-hosted by his wife, [[Tammy Faye Bakker]]. Bakker and his staff built what became known as the PTL Television Network (later named The Inspirational Network), a worldwide Christian satellite cable television network. In a ''[[The Tonight Show|Tonight Show]]''-type format, the program featured many well-known ministers and Christian recording artists. In the beginning, "Uncle Henry" Harrison (who had worked with Bakker at CBN) was the co-host/sidekick (much like [[Ed McMahon]] to [[Johnny Carson]]), and when Tammy Faye took over as co-host, Harrison became just the announcer.{{cite web|title=PTL Considering Future|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1987/PTL-Considering-Future-Of-Bakker-s-Parents-At-Ministry/id-70322a18e9efc88cbe112383a72ad4d0| date=August 10, 1987|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=August 27, 2013}} The program was later broadcast from Bakker's Heritage Village ministry headquarters and complex on Park Road in Charlotte, and then moved to studios constructed at the ministry's new 2500-acre mixed use family theme park and resort in [[Fort Mill, South Carolina]] known as [[Heritage USA]]. Bakker's [[conspicuous consumption]] and [[prosperity gospel]] preaching led critics to claim that PTL stood for "Pass The Loot."{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} As time went on and as more stations had additional programming commitments by 1981, many opted to only run an hour of the ''PTL Club''. In the fall of 1982, the show was cut to an hour, at which length it remained until its cancellation. ===Scandal and subsequent demise=== Due to his involvement in highly publicized financial and sexual scandals, Bakker resigned on March 19, 1987. He turned the cable network, the [[Heritage USA]] complex and all ministry assets over to fellow televangelist [[Jerry Falwell]]. Falwell became CEO of parent company, Heritage Village Church & Missionary Fellowship, Inc. and assumed control of the network and of its flagship program. Falwell's involvement was deemed newsworthy,{{By whom|date=October 2012}} as the PTL ministries were a part of the [[Assemblies of God]] denomination and Falwell was a Baptist. Ministry supporters questioned Falwell's intentions and attributed his interest solely to maintaining control of the lucrative cable-television empire owned by PTL to broadcast his own ministry programming. One commentator noted that "Bakker arranged for Falwell to take over PTL in March in an effort to avoid what he called a 'hostile takeover' of the television ministry by people threatening to expose a sexual encounter he admitted to having had seven years earlier with church secretary [[Jessica Hahn]]." Steve Baker. [http://www.skepticfiles.org/cultinfo/taxscams.htm PTL-Falwell] Associated Press. July 21, 1987. According to Hahn, on the afternoon of December 6, 1980, when she was a 21-year-old church secretary, Bakker and another preacher, John Wesley Fletcher drugged her and raped her for "about 15 minutes". Hahn stated she overheard Bakker say afterward to another PTL staffer, "Did you get her too?" [http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0507/14/lkl.01.html Transcript of interview] with [[Larry King]], [[CNN]], July 14, 2005. A federal grand jury indicted Bakker for directing millions of dollars of church funds to personal use. Much of the nation{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} watched the court case to see the outcome of the $165 million in donations.{{Cite web|url= http://www.gospelgrace.com/falseprophets/jimbakker/JimBakker.html Jim Bakker|title=Jim Bakker|publisher= GospelGrace.com|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070830053605/http://www.gospelgrace.com/falseprophets/jimbakker/JimBakker.html |archivedate=August 30, 2007}} {{cite news | last=Ostling|first=Richard N. |authorlink=Richard N. Ostling | title=Jim Bakker's Crumbling World | date=December 19, 1988 | work=[[Time (magazine)|''Time'' magazine]] |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,956551,00.html | accessdate=December 5, 2007}} ''The PTL Club'' continued as a television program for considerable time after this, first with Falwell as its host and PTL personality [[Doug Oldham]] as co-host. Falwell later brought in Christian singer Gary McSpadden as the show's co-host, along with PTL musical talent Ron Aldridge. The show was renamed ''PTL Today'', then — in an effort to distance the show from the PTL name — ''Heritage Today''. Aldridge continued as co-host alongside another PTL singer, Brenda Davis, after Falwell suddenly resigned from the now-bankrupt PTL ministry. McSpadden and Oldham subsequently left the show out of support for Falwell's decision to resign his position with the ministry. With Falwell's resignation, Sam Johnson, a member of the PTL ministry team, assumed leadership and incorporated a new entity known as Heritage Ministries to run the television program and associated ministry functions. As Heritage USA and the PTL assets were now tied up in bankruptcy reorganization, the new ministry and the television program had to move from their longtime Heritage USA broadcast studios to newly purchased property on Nations Ford Road in Charlotte that was named Heritage Place. The program remained on the air as late as September 1988, when Johnson faced problems with the IRS. [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/73632873.html?dids=73632873:73632873&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+24%2C+1988&author=&pub=The+Washington+Post+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=IRS+Asks+Court+to+Stop+PTL+Show&pqatl=google IRS Asks Court to Stop PTL Show] In 1989, evangelist [[Morris Cerullo]] purchased the network out of bankruptcy. {{As of | 2012}} it operates as [[The Inspiration Network|INSP]] from broadcast facilities in Charlotte, with headquarters in nearby [[Indian Land, South Carolina]]. On August 23, 1991, after the second and final day of his re-sentencing hearing, the court reduced Bakker's original 45-year sentence to 18 years, five of which he actually served before being released. In February 2009, [[Atlanta, Georgia]] investment-banker Ben Dyer announced his intention to auction off over 15,000 hours of videotaped episodes of ''The PTL Club'' on March 27, 2009. {{Cite web| url = http://goodscares.blogspot.com/2009/03/salvation-for-sale.html | title = Jim and Tammy Faye Bakker's old shows up for sale | accessdate =March 1, 2009 |date =February 28, 2009 |publisher = Associated Press }} A friend of Jim Bakker's purchased the programs. The master library of PTL programming has been returned to Jim Bakker, and the old tapes are being digitally remastered and restored. Restored programs are being run on the new PTL Television Network on [[Roku]] and online at the PTL Television Network's website. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0125638}} *[http://www.ptlnetwork.com PTL Television Network] {{PTL scandal}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ptl Club}} [[Category:1970s American television series]] [[Category:1974 American television series debuts]] [[Category:1980s American television series]] [[Category:1989 American television series endings]] [[Category:American television talk shows]] [[Category:Christian entertainment television series]] [[Category:Christian media]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Evangelicalism in the United States]] [[Category:Political organizations in the United States]]

{{about|the Jainism term|other uses|Tirtha (disambiguation)}} {{Jainism}} [[Image:delwada.jpg|thumb|right|Adishwar Temple, one of the [[Dilwara Temples]], [[Mount Abu]].]] [[Image:Gomateswara.jpg|thumb|right|The Gomatheswara at [[Shravanabelagola]] 978-993 AD.]]
In [[Jainism]], a '''tīrtha''' ({{lang-sa|तीर्थ}} "[[Ford (crossing)|ford]], a shallow part of a body of water that may be easily crossed") is used to refer both to [[pilgrimage]] sites as well as to the four sections of the [[sangha (Jainism)|sangha]]. A tirtha provides the inspiration to enable one to cross over from worldly engagement to the side of [[Moksha (Jainism)|moksha]].<ref>[http://www.jsgc.org/tirth.htm Special features of sacred places of Jains] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090413051722/http://www.jsgc.org/tirth.htm |date=2009-04-13 }}</ref>
Jain tirthas are located throughout India. Often a tirtha has a number of temples as well as residences (dharmashala) for the pilgrims and wandering monks and scholars.
==Types== Tirtha sites include:<ref>Jainism: A Pictorial Guide to the Religion of Non-Violence, Kurt Titze, Motilal Banarsidass; 2nd edition (March 5, 2001)</ref>
* ''Siddhakshetra''s or site of [[Moksha (Jainism)|moksha]] liberation of an [[Arihant (Jainism)|arihant]] (''kevalin'') or [[Tirthankara]]s like [[Mount Kailash|Ashtapada Hill]], [[Shikharji]], [[Girnar]], [[Pawapuri]], [[Palitana]], [[Mangi-Tungi]] and [[Champapuri]] (capital of [[Anga]]) * ''Atishayakshetra''s where divine events have occurred like [[Mahavirji]], [[Rishabhdeo]], [[Kundalpur]], [[Aharji]] etc. * ''Puranakshetra''s associated with lives of great men like [[Ayodhya]], [[Vidisha]], [[Hastinapur]], and [[Rajgir]] * ''Gyanakshetra'': associated with famous [[acharya]]s or centers of learning like [[Mohankheda]], [[Shravanabelagola]] and [[Ladnu]]
==Locations== Geographically, the tirthas are divided into six quarters:<ref>Bharat ke Digambar Jain Tirth, Volume 1, Balbhadra Jain, 1974</ref> * ''North India'': [[Hastinapur]], [[Taxila]], and [[Mount Kailash|Ashtapada]] * ''South India'': [[Shravanabelagola]], [[Sankighatta]], [[Moodabidri]], [[Humbaj]], [[Anantnath Swami Temple]], [[Gummileru]] * ''Eastern India'': [[Shikharji]], [[Pawapuri]], [[Champapuri]], [[Pundravardhana]] * ''Western India'': [[Palitana temples|Palitana]], [[Girnar]], [[Mount Abu]], [[Shri Mahavirji|Mahavirji]], [[Shankheshwar]], [[Mahudi]] * ''Central India'': [[Vidisha]], [[Kundalpur]], [[Sonagiri]], [[Muktagiri]] * ''Overseas'': [[Siddhachalam]], [[Nava Ashtapada]], [[Siddhayatan]]
==See also== {{portal|Jainism}} *[[Jain temple]] *[[Vividha Tirtha Kalpa]] *[[Tirtha (Hinduism)]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.jainuniversity.org jainuniversity.org], Jain Tirtha all over India * [http://www.jainteerth.com http://www.jainteerth.com] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060207190638/http://tirth.jinvani.com/index.php http://tirth.jinvani.com] * [http://www.jainpilgrimages.com http://www.jainpilgrimages.com] * [http://www.jaintirths.com http://www.jaintirths.com] * [http://www.siddhayatan.org/ http://www.siddhayatan.org] First Hindu-Jain Tirth in North America * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091229160433/http://www.jainheritagecentres.com/Jainism_In_India.htm http://www.jainheritagecentres.com] * [http://www.nageshwartirth.org/index.php Shri Nageshwar Parshwanath] * [http://www.jainreligion.in/jain-tirth/Jain-Tirth-Jain-Teerth-Darshan.asp Jain Tirth Darshan on jainreligion.in]
{{Jainism topics}}

revision.text:
{{Tone|date=August 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Tunde Bakare | birth_name = Babatunde Gbolahan Bakare | image = File:Pastor Tunde Bakare.jpg | birth_date = 11 November 1954 | birth_place = Abeokuta, Ogun State, Nigeria | residence = [[Lagos]], Nigeria | education = [[University of Lagos]], Nigeria | occupation = [[Teacher]], [[Lawyer]] and [[Author]] | website = {{URL |http://www.tundebakare.com/}}
}} '''Tunde Bakare''' is a [[Nigerian]] [[Prophetic]]-[[wikt:apostolic|Apostolic]] pastor. He has received national and international attention for his [[televangelism]], which has sometimes been critical of the [[Politics of Nigeria|Nigerian government]].<ref>{{Cite book |page=174 |year=2004 |publisher=Routledge |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WW-XcDe-IMEC |title=New religious movements in the twenty-first century }}</ref> He was reportedly arrested in March 2002 after preaching sermons critical of then-president [[Olusegun Obasanjo]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?sf=86&set_id=1&click_id=68&art_id=qw1015158240108B252 |publisher=The Independent (South Africa) |accessdate=26 April 2009 |date=3 March 2002 |title=Nigeria's 'prophet of doom' detained }}</ref>
He has appeared as a preacher on [[Africa Independent Television|AIT]] television. The Nigerian presidential candidate of the [[Congress for Progressive Change]], CPC, Gen. [[Muhammadu Buhari]], on Monday, 31 January, announced Pastor Tunde Bakare of the Latter Rain Assembly, [[Lagos]] as his running mate for the [[2011 Nigerian presidential election]] which he accepted. CPC lost the presidential election to PDP, and Pastor Bakare remains a fierce critic of the Nigerian government and leadership. He was formerly a pastor at the [[Deeper Life Bible Church]] before he left to join the [[Redeemed Christian Church of God]] which he soon left to form his own.
==Early life== Pastor Bakare attended All Saints Primary School, Kemta, Abeokuta and subsequently [[Lisabi Grammar School]], [[Abeokuta]], after which he studied law at the University of Lagos between 1977 and 1980. He was called to the Bar in 1981 and following his NYSC, he practiced law with Gani Fawehinmi Chambers, Rotimi Williams & Co and Burke & Co, Solicitors. He established his own law firm Tunde Bakare & Co (El-Shaddai Chambers) in October 1984.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bakare|first1=Tunde|title=About Tunde Bakare|url=http://tundebakare.com/about/|website=http://tundebakare.com}}</ref>
In May 1988, at the peak of his legal career he was called into ministry and he founded The Latter Rain Assembly (End-Time Church) on 1 April 1989 and is currently the Serving Overseer of the church.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Latter Rain Assembly|title=About|url=http://lraglobal.org/the-executive-team/|website=https://lraglobal.org/}}</ref>
He presides over Global Apostolic Impact Network (GAIN) – a network of churches, ministries and kingdom businesses committed to advancing the Kingdom of God on earth. Dr. Bakare is also the President of Latter Rain Ministries, Inc. (Church Development Center) in Atlanta, GA, USA, a ministry committed to restoring today’s church to the scriptural pattern. In recognition of his years of exploits and global impact in ministry, he was honoured with a Doctor of Ministry degree by the Indiana Christian University under the leadership of his mentor, Dr. Lester Sumrall in 1996.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bakare|first1=Tunde|title=About Tunde Bakare|url=http://tundebakare.com/about/|website=http://tundebakare.com}}</ref>
==Convictions== His persuasion: "I’m fully persuaded that I will live long in health; having long life in health, with wealth for the purpose for which He created me to be a blessing to humanity". This persuasion invariably affects and informs his thought patterns, decision making process and choices in life.
His conviction: "God will not justify the wicked, He will not forsake the righteous; the wickedness of a wicked man will fall upon his head and the righteousness of a righteous man will answer for him in the days to come".
"The minority that is right will become the majority and the majority that is wrong will become the minority, it’s just a matter of time".
His passion: "To see that the true perspective of the gospel of Jesus Christ is given to people without any contamination or mixture" and "To see a Nigeria that works in his lifetime".
His Legacy: "My legacy? The grace to pray through". Surprisingly, Pastor Bakare initially as a young Christian did not have a flare or desire to pray, but according to him, circumstances in his marriage as orchestrated by God taught him not only how to pray but also how to pray through.
Secret of his success: Obedience only to the word and instructions of God. Sandwiched between his willingness and desire to do the will of God is obedience even when all things are working contrary to the word of God.
==Personal life== Pastor (Dr.) ‘Tunde Bakare was born to a [[Muslim]] mother and a Muslim father, whom he did not grow up to know. His mother, Madam Abigail Eebudola Bakare raised him. Married to Mrs. Olayide Bakare in 1984, Pastor Bakare’s marriage has played a pivotal role in his life, career and ministry. "Mrs. B", as she is affectionately called by her husband, has been involved in ministry work all her adult life. Pastor and Mrs. Bakare have raised two girls and three boys in their over thirty years of marriage.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bakare|first1=Tunde|title=About Tunde Bakare|url=http://tundebakare.com/about/|website=http://tundebakare.com}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website}}

{{Zoroastrianism}} '''Yasna''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|j|ʌ|s|n|ə}};[http://www.dictionary.com/browse/yasna "Yasna"]. ''[[Random House Webster's Unabridged Dictionary]]''. {{lang-ae|𐬫𐬀𐬯𐬥𐬀}}) is the [[Avestan]] name of [[Zoroastrianism]]'s principal act of worship. It is also the name of the primary liturgical collection of [[Avesta]] texts, recited during that ''yasna'' ceremony. ==Overview== The function of the ''yasna'' ceremony is, very roughly described, to strengthen the orderly spiritual and material creations of [[Ahura Mazda]] against the assault of the destructive forces of [[Angra Mainyu]]. The ''yasna'' service, that is, the recitation of the Yasna texts, culminates in the ''[[Ab-Zohr|apæ zaothra]]'', the "offering to the waters." The ceremony may also be extended by recitation of the ''[[Visperad]]'' and ''[[Vendidad]]'' texts. A normal ''yasna'' ceremony, without extensions, takes about two hours when it is recited by an experienced priest. The ''Yasna'' texts constitute 72 chapters altogether, composed at different times and by different authors. The middle chapters include of the (linguistically) oldest texts of the Zoroastrian canon. These very ancient texts, in the very archaic and linguistically difficult [[Old Avestan]] language, include the four most sacred Zoroastrian prayers, and also 17 chapters comprising the five [[Gathas]], hymns that are considered to have been composed by Zoroaster himself. Several sections of the ''Yasna'' include [[exegesis|exegetical]] comments. ''Yasna'' chapter and verse pointers are traditionally abbreviated with ''Y.'' The Avestan language word ''yasna'' literally means 'oblation' or 'worship'. The word is linguistically related to (but not the functional equivalent of) [[Vedic Sanskrit]] ''[[yajna]]''. Unlike Sanskrit ''yajna'', which refers to a class of rituals, Zoroastrian ''yasna'' is a particular liturgy and ritual, and the ritual has "to do with water rather than fire."{{sfn|Drower|1944|p=78}}{{sfn|Boyce|1975|pp=147-191}} ==The service== The theological function of the ''yasna'' ceremony, and the proper performance of it, is to further ''[[asha]]'', that is, the ceremony aims to strengthen that which is right/true (one meaning of ''asha'') in the existence/creation (another meaning of ''asha'') of divine order (yet another meaning of ''asha''). The [[Encyclopedia Iranica]] summarizes the aim of the ''yasna'' ceremony as "the maintenance of the cosmic integrity of the good creation of [[Ahura Mazda|Ahura Mazdā]]."{{sfn|Malandra|2006}} Zoroastrianism's cosmological/eschatological perception of the purpose of humankind is to strengthen the orderly spiritual and material creations of Mazda against the assault of the destructive forces of [[Angra Mainyu]]. In that conflict, theologically speaking, mankind's primary weapon is the ''yasna'' ceremony, which is understood to have a direct, immediate effect: "[f]ar from being a symbolic act, the proper performance of the yasna is what prevents the cosmos from falling into chaos."{{sfn|Malandra|2006}} The culminating act of the ''yasna'' ceremony is the [[Ab-Zohr]], the "strengthening of the waters". The ''Yasna'' service, that is, the recitation of the Yasna texts, culminates in the ''[[Ab-Zohr]]'', the "offering to waters". The ''Yasna'' ceremony may be extended by recitation of the ''[[Visperad]]'' and ''[[Vendidad]]''. A well-trained priest is able to recite the entire ''Yasna'' in about two hours.{{sfn|Stausberg|2004|pp=337,n131}} With extensions, it takes about an hour longer. In its normal form, the ''Yasna'' ceremony is only to be performed in the morning. ==The liturgy== ===Structure and organization=== {| |- |The texts of the ''Yasna'' are organized into 72 chapters, known as ''had''s or ''ha''s (from Avestan ''ha'iti'', 'cut'). The 72 threads of the Zoroastrian [[Kushti|Kusti]] the sacred girdle worn around the waist - represent the 72 chapters of the ''Yasna''. From a literary point of view, the 72 chapters consist of two nested inner cores, and an outer envelope. The outer chapters/sections (the "envelope") are in the [[Avestan language|Younger Avestan]] language. The middle 27 chapters include the (linguistically) oldest texts of the Zoroastrian canon. The inner chapters/sections (excepting chapters 42.1-4,52.5-8) are in the more archaic [[Old Avestan]] language, with the four sacred formulae bracketing the innermost core. This innermost core includes the 17 chapters of the [[Gathas]], the oldest and most sacred texts of the Zoroastrian canon. :Yasna 1-27.12 ::Yasna 27.13-27.15: three of the four of the most sacred Zoroastrian prayers :::Yasna 28-34: [[Gatha]] 1 ::::Yasna 35-41: the "seven-chapter Yasna" :::Yasna 43-51,53: Gathas 2-5 (chapters 43-46, 47-50, 51 and 53) ::Yasna 54.1: fourth of four of the most sacred Zoroastrian prayers :Yasna 54.2-72 From a ritual point of view, the liturgy can be broken into 4 major sections, each having its own internal prelude: :: Chapter 1-12: Invitation of the divinities to the worship :: Chapter 13-59: The Staota Yesniia :: Chapter 60-69: The culmination of the Yasna (the "[[Ab-Zohr]]"), accompanied by intense ritual activity. :: Chapter 70-72: Conclusion and thanks to the divinities for attending Some sections of the ''Yasna'' occur more than once. For instance, ''Yasna'' 5 is repeated as ''Yasna'' 37, and ''Yasna'' 63 consists of passages from ''Yasna'' 15.2, 66.2 and 38.3. The ability to recite the ''Yasna'' from memory is one of the prerequisites for Zoroastrian priesthood. |} ===Content summaries=== * '''''Yasna'' 1''' opens with the praise of [[Ahura Mazda]], enumerating his divine titles as the Creator, "radiant, glorious, the greatest, the best, the most beautiful, the most firm, the most wise, of the most perfect form, the highest in righteousness, possessed of great joy, creator, fashioner, nourisher, and the Most Holy Spirit." (Dhalla, 1936:155). ''Yasna'' 1 then enumerates the divinities, inviting them to the service. * '''''Yasna'' 2''', the ''Barsom [[Yasht]]'', presents libation and the ''barsom'' (a bundle of 23 twigs bound together, symbolizing sanctity) to the invited divinities. ''Yasna'' 2-4 complement ''Yasna'' 1. Most verses in ''Yasna'' 2-3 begin with the formula ''ayese yeshti …'', "by means of this sacrifice, I call …", followed by the name of the divinity being invoked. * '''''Yasna'' 3-8''' known collectively as the ''[[Sarosh]] dron'', presents other offerings (''zaothra''). ''Yasna'' 3 draws the attention of the divinities invoked in ''Yasna'' 1, and in ''Yasna'' 4, the offerings are consecrated to the divinities. ''Yasna'' 5 is repeated in ''Yasna'' 37. ''Yasna'' 6 is almost identical to the first 10 verses of ''Yasna'' 17. * '''''Yasna'' 9-11''' is the ''Hom [[Yasht]]'', a collection of accolades to the [[Haoma]] plant and its divinity. * '''''Yasna'' 12''' constitutes the ''Fravarane'', the Zoroastrian creed and declaration of faith. It is in "Artificial" Gathic Avestan, that is, it is stylistically and linguistically aligned with the language of the ''[[Gathas]]'', but imperfectly. The last strophe of verse 7 as well as all of verses 8 and 9 are incorporated into the ''Kusti'' ritual. * '''''Yasna'' 13-18''' are comparable to ''Yasna'' 1-8 in that they too are a collection of invocations to the divinities. Chapters 14-18 serve as an introduction to the ''Staota Yesniia'' of ''Yasna'' 19-59. The first 10 verses of ''Yasna'' 17, "to the fires, waters, plants", is almost identical to ''Yasna'' 6. * '''''Yasna'' 19-21''', the Bhagan ''Yasht'', are commentaries on the three 'high prayers' of ''Yasna'' 28-53. * '''''Yasna'' 22-26''' is another set of invocations to the divinities. * '''''Yasna'' 27''' has the prayers referred to by ''Yasna'' 19-21. These are: ** The ''[[Ahuna Vairya]]'' invocation (also known as the ''Yatha Ahu Vairyo''), the most sacred of all Zoroastrian prayers. ** The ''[[Ashem Vohu]]'' ** The ''Yenghe hatam'' * [[File:Bodleian J2 fol 175 Y 28 1.jpg|right|thumb|250px|''Yasna'' 28.1, [[Gathas|''Ahunavaiti'' Gatha]] (Bodleian MS J2)]]'''''Yasna'' 28-53''' include the (linguistically) oldest texts of the Zoroastrian canon. 17 of the 26 chapters make up the [[Gathas]], the most sacred hymns of Zoroastrianism and thought to have been composed by [[Zoroaster]] himself. The Gathas are in verse. These are structurally interrupted by a) the ''Yasna Haptanghaiti'' ("seven-chapter ''Yasna''", #35-41), which is as old as the Gathas but in prose, b) two short chapters (#42 and #52) that are not as old as the Gathas and ''Yasna Haptanghaiti''. ** '''''Yasna'' 28-34''': [[Gathas|''Ahunavaiti'' Gatha]] ** '''''Yasna'' 35-41''': ''[[Yasna Haptanghaiti]]'', the "seven-chapter ''Yasna''", also in Gathic Avestan but in prose. ** '''''Yasna'' 42''': a 4 verse chapter invoking the elements. ** '''''Yasna'' 43-46''': [[Gathas|''Ushtavait'' Gatha]] ** '''''Yasna'' 47-50''': [[Gathas|''Spenta Mainyu'' Gatha]] ** '''''Yasna'' 51''': [[Gathas|''Vohu Khshathra'' Gatha]] ** '''''Yasna'' 52''': an 8 verse hymn to [[Ashi]]. Verses 52.5 - 52.8, in Younger Avestan, are a duplicate of ''Yasna'' 8.5 - 8.8. ** '''''Yasna'' 53''': [[Gathas|''Vahishto Ishti'' Gatha]] * '''''Yasna'' 54''' has the text of the ''[[Airyaman ishya|a airiiema ishiio]]'', a prayer referred to in ''Yasna'' 27. * '''''Yasna'' 55''' is a praise to the ''Gathas'' and the ''Staota Yesniia''. * '''''Yasna'' 56''' is again an invocation to the divinities, appealing for their attention. * '''''Yasna'' 57''' is the ''[[Sarosh]] Yasht'', the hymn to the divinity of religious discipline. It is closely related to, and appears to have sections borrowed from ''Yasht'' 10, the hymn to [[Mithra]]. * '''''Yasna'' 58''' is again a "hidden" ''Yasht'', here to the genius of prayer (''cf.'' [[Dahman]]). * '''''Yasna'' 59''' is a repetition of the sections from ''Yasna'' 17 and 26. * '''''Yasna'' 60''' is blessing upon the house of the ''[[ashavan]]'' ('just' or 'true' man). ''Yasna'' 60.2-7 constitute the [[Dahman|Dahma Afriti]] invocation, also known as the ''Afrinagan Dahman''. * '''''Yasna'' 61''' praises the anti-demonic powers imbued in the ''Afrinagan Dahman'', ''Yenghe hatam'' and the three principal prayers of ''Yasna'' 27. * '''''Yasna'' 62''' constitutes the ''[[Atar|Ataksh]] Nyashes'', prayers to fire and its divinity. * '''''Yasna'' 63-69''' constitute the prayers that accompany the ''[[Ab-Zohr]]'', "offering to water". * '''''Yasna'' 70-72''' are again a set of invocations to the divinities. ==References== ;Citations {{reflist|30em}} ;Bibliography
